Acting by means, or by an intervening cause or instrument; not direct or immediate; acting or suffering through an intervening agent or condition
Gained or effected by a medium or condition
To be in the middle, or between two; to intervene
To interpose between parties, as the equal friend of each, esp. for the purpose of effecting a reconciliation or agreement; as, to mediate between nations
To effect by mediation or interposition; to bring about as a mediator, instrument, or means; as, to mediate a peace
To divide into two equal parts

mediately.definition: In a mediate manner; by a secondary cause or agent; not directly or primarily; by means; -- opposed to immediately

mediation.definition: The act of mediating; action or relation of anything interposed; action as a necessary condition, means, or instrument; interposition; intervention
Hence, specifically, agency between parties at variance, with a view to reconcile them; entreaty for another; intercession

mediative.definition: Pertaining to mediation; used in mediation; as, mediative efforts

mediatize.definition: To cause to act through an agent or to hold a subordinate position; to annex; -- specifically applied to the annexation during the former German empire of a smaller German state to a larger, while allowing it a nominal sovereignty, and its prince his rank

mediator.definition: One who mediates; especially, one who interposes between parties at variance for the purpose of reconciling them; hence, an intercessor

mediatorial.definition: Of or pertaining to a mediator, or to mediation; mediatory; as, a mediatorial office

mediatorship.definition: The office or character of a mediator

medic.definition: A leguminous plant of the genus Medicago.  The black medic is the Medicago lupulina; the purple medic, or lucern, is Medicago sativa
A person who serves to provide medical care
A member of the medical corps in the military

medicable.definition: Capable of being medicated; admitting of being cured or healed

medicaid.definition: A program controlled by the United States government to provide health care for the needy.  It is funded by contributions from the salaries of workers, and is therefore a form of health insurance

medical.definition: Of, pertaining to, or having to do with, the art of healing disease, or the science of medicine; as, the medical profession; medical services; a medical dictionary; medical jurisprudence
Containing medicine; used in medicine; medicinal; as, the medical properties of a plant

medically.definition: In a medical manner; with reference to healing, or to the principles of the healing art

medicament.definition: Anything used for healing diseases or wounds, especially a medicine; a medication; a healing application

medicamental.definition: Of or pertaining to medicaments or healing applications; having the qualities of medicaments

medicate.definition: To tincture or impregnate with anything medicinal; to drug

medication.definition: The act or process of medicating

medicean.definition: Of or relating to the Medici, a noted Italian family; as, the Medicean Venus

medicinable.definition: Medicinal; having the power of healing

medicinal.definition: Having curative or palliative properties; used for the cure or alleviation of bodily disorders; as, medicinal tinctures, plants, or springs
Of or pertaining to medicine; medical

medicine.definition: The science which relates to the prevention, cure, or alleviation of disease
Any substance administered in the treatment of disease; a remedial agent; a medication; a drug; a pharmaceutical; a medicament; a remedy; physic

Among the North American Indians, any object supposed to give control over natural or magical forces, to act as a protective charm, or to cause healing; also, magical power itself; the potency which a charm, token, or rite is supposed to exert
Hence, a similar object or agency among other savages
To give medicine to; to affect as a medicine does; to remedy; to cure

medick.definition: Any of several Old World herbs of the genus Medicago having small flowers and trifoliate compound leaves

synonyms: Syn. -- doctor, doc, physician, MD, Dr.

medico-legal.definition: Of or pertaining to law as affected by medical facts

medicommissure.definition: A large transverse commissure in the third ventricle of the brain; the middle or soft commissure

medicornu.definition: The middle or inferior horn of each lateral ventricle of the brain

medina epoch.definition: A subdivision of the Niagara period in the American upper Silurian, characterized by the formations known as the Oneida conglomerate, and the Medina sandstone. See the Chart of Geology

medinilla.definition: A genus of tropical Old World ornamental evergreen shrubs having fleshy leaves and large panicles of white pink flowers

mediocre.definition: Of a middle quality; of but a moderate or low degree of excellence; indifferent; ordinary
A young monk who was excused from performing a portion of a monk's duties

mediocrity.definition: The quality of being mediocre; a middle state or degree; a moderate degree or rate

mediostapedial.definition: Pertaining to that part of the columella of the ear which, in some animals, connects the stapes with the other parts of the columella

meditate.definition: To keep the mind in a state of contemplation; to dwell on anything in thought; to think seriously; to muse; to cogitate; to reflect
To contemplate; to keep the mind fixed upon; to study
To purpose; to intend; to design; to plan by revolving in the mind; as, to meditate a war

meditation.definition: The act of meditating; close or continued thought; the turning or revolving of a subject in the mind; serious contemplation; reflection; musing

meditatist.definition: One who is given to meditation

meditative.definition: Disposed to meditate, or to meditation; as, a meditative man; a meditative mood

mediterranean.definition: Inclosed, or nearly inclosed, with land; as, the Mediterranean Sea, between Europe and Africa
Of, pertaining to, or located in the Mediterranean Sea or on the adjacent lands; as, Mediterranean trade; a Mediterranean voyage; a Mediterranean plant

mediterranean fruit fly.definition: A small two-winged fly (Ceratitis capitata), a native of the Mediterranean countries but now widely distributed in warm regions, which can cause great damage to citrus and other succulent fruit crops when present in large numbers.  It is black and white and irregularly banded. It lays eggs in ripening oranges, peaches, and other fruits; when the eggs hatch into larvae (maggots) inside the fruit, they cause the fruit to decay and fall, and make the fruit unsaleable.  It is also popularly called the medfly

medium.definition: That which lies in the middle, or between other things; intervening body or quantity
A substance through which an effect is transmitted from one thing to another; as, air is the common medium of sound
A trade name for printing and writing paper of certain sizes. See Paper
The liquid vehicle with which dry colors are ground and prepared for application

A source of nutrients in which a microorganism is placed to permit its growth, cause it to produce substances, or observe its activity under defined conditions; also called culture medium or growth medium.  The medium is usually a solution of nutrients in water, or a similar solution solidified with gelatin or agar

A means of transmission of news, advertising, or other messages from an information source to the public, also called a news medium, such as a newspaper or radio; used mostly in the plural form, i. e. news media or media.  See 1st media{2}
Having a middle position or degree; mean; intermediate; medial; as, a horse of medium size; a decoction of medium strength

medium-sized.definition: Having a medium size; as, a medium-sized man

medius.definition: The third or middle finger; the third digit, or that which corresponds to it

medjidie.definition: A silver coin of Turkey formerly rated at twenty, but since 1880 at nineteen, piasters (about 83 cents)
A Turkish honorary order established in 1851 by Abdul-Mejid, having as its badge a medallion surrounded by seven silver rays and crescents. It is often conferred on foreigners

medlar.definition: A tree of the genus Mespilus (Mespilus Germanica); also, the fruit of the tree.  The fruit is something like a small apple, but has a bony endocarp.  When first gathered the flesh is hard and austere, and it is not eaten until it has begun to decay

medle.definition: To mix; to mingle; to meddle

medley.definition: A mixture; a mingled and confused mass of ingredients, usually inharmonious; a jumble; a hodgepodge; -- often used contemptuously
The confusion of a hand to hand battle; a brisk, hand to hand engagement; a mêlée
A composition of passages detached from several different compositions; a potpourri
Mixed; of mixed material or color

medoc.definition: A class of claret wines, including several varieties, from the district of Médoc in the department of Gironde

medrick.definition: A species of gull or tern

medulla.definition: The marrow of bones; the deep or inner portion of an organ or part; as, the medulla, or medullary substance, of the kidney; specifically, the medula oblongata
A soft tissue, occupying the center of the stem or branch of a plant; pith

medullary.definition: Pertaining to, consisting of, or resembling, marrow or medulla

medullated.definition: Furnished with a medulla or marrow, or with a medullary sheath; as, a medullated nerve fiber

medullin.definition: A variety of lignin or cellulose found in the medulla, or pith, of certain plants.  Cf. Lignin, and Cellulose

medusa.definition: The Gorgon; or one of the Gorgons whose hair was changed into serpents, after which all who looked upon her were turned into stone
Any free swimming acaleph; a jellyfish

medusiform.definition: Resembling a medusa in shape or structure

medusoid.definition: Like a medusa; having the fundamental structure of a medusa, but without a locomotive disk; -- said of the sessile gonophores of hydroids

meed.definition: That which is bestowed or rendered in consideration of merit; reward; recompense

meedful.definition: Worthy of meed, reward, or recompense; meritorious

meek.definition: Mild of temper; not easily provoked or orritated; patient under injuries; not vain, or haughty, or resentful; forbearing; submissive
Evincing mildness of temper, or patience; characterized by mildness or patience; as, a meek answer; a meek face
To make meek; to nurture in gentleness and humility

meekness.definition: The quality or state of being meek

meerkat.definition: A South African carnivore (Suricata suricata, formerly Cynictis penicillata), allied to the ichneumons, having a lemurlike face and only four toes; called also yellow mongoose and suricate

meerschaum.definition: A fine white claylike mineral, soft, and light enough when in dry masses to float in water.  It is a hydrous silicate of magnesia, and is obtained chiefly in Asia Minor.  It is manufacturd into tobacco pipes, cigar holders, etc. Also called sepiolite
A tobacco pipe made of this mineral; a meerschaum pipe

meet.definition: To join, or come in contact with; esp., to come in contact with by approach from an opposite direction; to come upon or against, front to front, as distinguished from contact by following and overtaking
To come in collision with; to confront in conflict; to encounter hostilely; as, they met the enemy and defeated them; the ship met opposing winds and currents

To come into the presence of without contact; to come close to; to intercept; to come within the perception, influence, or recognition of; as, to meet a train at a junction; to meet carriages or persons in the street; to meet friends at a party; sweet sounds met the ear
To perceive; to come to a knowledge of; to have personal acquaintance with; to experience; to suffer; as, the eye met a horrid sight; he met his fate
To come up to; to be even with; to equal; to match; to satisfy; to ansver; as, to meet one's expectations; the supply meets the demand

To come together by mutual approach; esp., to come in contact, or into proximity, by approach from opposite directions; to join; to come face to face; to come in close relationship; as, we met in the street; two lines meet so as to form an angle
To come together with hostile purpose; to have an encounter or conflict
To assemble together; to congregate; as, Congress meets on the first Monday of December
To come together by mutual concessions; hence, to agree; to harmonize; to unite
An assembling together; esp., the assembling of huntsmen for the hunt; also, the persons who so assemble, and the place of meeting
Suitable; fit; proper; appropriate; qualified; convenient

meeting.definition: A coming together; an assembling; as, the meeting of Congress
A junction, crossing, or union; as, the meeting of the roads or of two rivers
A congregation; a collection of people; a convention; as, a large meeting; an harmonious meeting
An assembly for worship; as, to attend meeting on Sunday; -- in England, applied distinctively and disparagingly to the worshiping assemblies of Dissenters

meetinghouse.definition: A house used as a place of worship; a church; -- in England, applied only to a house so used by Dissenters

meg-.definition: Combining forms signifying: (a) Great, extended, powerful; as, megascope, megacosm

megacephalic.definition: Large headed; -- applied to animals, and to plants when they have large flower heads

megachile.definition: A leaf-cutting bee of the genus Megachilus. See Leaf cutter, under Leaf

megaderm.definition: Any one of several species of Old World blood-sucking bats of the genus Megaderma

megadyne.definition: One of the larger measures of force, amounting to one million dynes

megafarad.definition: One of the larger measures of electrical capacitance, amounting to one million farads; a macrofarad

megakaryocyte.definition: A large bone marrow cell not usually found in the circulating blood; it is regarded as the precursors of blood platelets; it is up to 100 μm in diameter, with a polyploid nucleus.  Also referred to as megacaryocyte, megalokaryocyte, and thromboblast

megakaryocytic.definition: Of or pertaining to a megakaryocyte

megalesian.definition: Pertaining to, or in honor of, Cybele; as, the Megalesian games at Rome

megalethoscope.definition: An optical apparatus in which pictures are viewed through a large lens with stereoptical effects.  It is often combined with the stereoscope

megalith.definition: A large stone; especially, a large stone used in constructing ancient monuments

megalithic.definition: Of or pertaining to megaliths or the period during which they were erected; as, megalithic monuments like Stonehenge

megalobatrachus.definition: A genus of giant salamanders; in some classifications included in the genus Cryptobranchus

megalocephalia.definition: The condition of having an abnormally large head; called also megacephaly

megalocyte.definition: A large, flattened red blood cell corpuscle having no nucleus, twice the diameter of the ordinary red corpuscle, found in considerable numbers in the blood in profound anaemia

megalomania.definition: A form of mental alienation in which the patient has grandiose delusions

megalonychidae.definition: A natural family consisting of the two-toed sloths

megalonyx.definition: An extinct quaternary mammal, of great size, allied to the sloth

megalops.definition: A larva, in a stage following the zoea, in the development of most crabs. In this stage the legs and abdominal appendages have appeared, the abdomen is relatively long, and the eyes are large. Also used adjectively

megalosaur.definition: A gigantic carnivorous dinosaur, whose fossil remains have been found in England and elsewhere

megameter.definition: An instrument for determining longitude by observation of the stars
In the metric system, one million meters, or one thousand kilometers

megaphone.definition: A device to magnify sound, or direct it in a given direction in a greater volume, as a very large funnel used as an ear trumpet or as a speaking trumpet

megaphyton.definition: An extinct genus of tree ferns with large, two-ranked leaves, or fronds

megapode.definition: Any one of several species of large-footed, gallinaceous birds of the genera Megapodius and Leipoa, inhabiting Australia and other Pacific islands.  Called also mound builder, scrub fowl, moundbird, and brush turkey.  See Jungle fowl (b) under Jungle, and Leipoa

megapolis.definition: A chief city; a very large cuity; a metropolis
A region in which the suburbs of several large cities merge to form one large predominantly urbanized area

megarian.definition: Belonging, or pertaining, to Megara, a city of ancient Greece

megascope.definition: A modification of the magic lantern (projector), used esp. for throwing a magnified image of an opaque object on a screen, solar or artificial light being used

megascopic.definition: Of or pertaining to the megascope or the projection upon a screen of images of opaque objects
Large enough to be seen; -- said of the larger structural features and components of rocks which do not require the use of the microscope to be perceived. Opposed to microscopic

megaseme.definition: Having the orbital index relatively large; having the orbits narrow transversely; -- opposed to microseme

megasthene.definition: One of a group which includes the higher orders of mammals, having a large size as a typical characteristic

megasthenic.definition: Having a typically large size; belonging to the megasthenes

megastome.definition: One of a group of univalve shells, having a large aperture or mouth

megathere.definition: An extinct gigantic quaternary mammal, allied to the ant-eaters and sloths. Its remains are found in South America

megatheroid.definition: One of a family of extinct edentates found in America. The family includes the megatherium, the megalonyx, etc

megavolt.definition: One of the larger measures of electro-motive force, amounting to one million volts

megerg.definition: One of the larger measures of work, amounting to one million ergs; -- called also megalerg

megilp.definition: A gelatinous compound of linseed oil and mastic varnish, used by artists as a vehicle for colors

mego.definition: A very dull article, speech, or book, which causes the reader or listener to rapidly lose interest; -- often used of involved discussions of a technical nature, especially in newspapers

megohm.definition: One of the larger measures of electrical resistance, amounting to one million ohms

megrim.definition: A kind of sick or nervous headache, usually periodical and confined to one side of the head; now more commonly called migraine headache or migraine
A fancy; a whim; a freak; a humor; esp., in the plural, lowness of spirits
A sudden vertigo in a horse, succeeded sometimes by unconsciousness, produced by an excess of blood in the brain; a mild form of apoplexy
The British smooth sole, or scaldfish (Psetta arnoglossa)

meibomian.definition: Of, pertaining to, or discovered by, Meibomius

meine.definition: A family, including servants, etc.; household; retinue; train

meionite.definition: A member of the scapolite group, occuring in glassy crystals on Monte Somma, near Naples

meiosis.definition: Diminution; a species of hyperbole, representing a thing as being less than it really is; understatement; see also litotes
The cellular process by which a diploid progenitor cell forms haploid gametes, including a division of one diploid cell into two cells, each with one of the homologous sets of chromosomes

meiostemonous.definition: Having fever stamens than the parts of the corolla

meiotic.definition: Of or pertaining to meiosis; as, meiotic division

melaconite.definition: An earthy black oxide of copper, arising from the decomposition of other ores

melada.definition: A mixture of sugar and molasses; crude sugar as it comes from the pans without being drained

melaena.definition: A discharge from the bowels of black matter, consisting of altered blood

melain.definition: The dark coloring matter of the liquid of the cuttlefish

melam.definition: A white or buff-colored granular powder, C6H9N11, obtained by heating ammonium sulphocyanate

melamine.definition: A nitrogenous strongly basic chemical substance (C3H6N6), structurally 2,4,6-triamino-1,3,5-triazine, produced from several cyanogen compounds, and obtained as a white crystalline substance; -- formerly supposed to be produced by the decomposition of melam.  Called also cyanuramide.  It is used as one of the starting components (together with formaldehyde) in the preparation of melamine resins, including the commercially marketed Formica (TM).  It is solid at room temperature, and sublimes at temperatures approaching 250° C, decomposing at 345° C.  Density 1.573

melamine resin.definition: A thermosetting plastic formed by the reaction of melamine and formaldehyde.  It is used for molding and for preparing laminated sheets used to surface counter tops, walls, and furniture.  The commercially marketed Formica (TM) is one type of melamine resin

melampsoraceae.definition: A natural family of rust fungi

melampyrin.definition: The saccharine substance dulcite; -- so called because found in the leaves of cowwheat (Melampyrum). See Dulcite

melanaemia.definition: A morbid condition in which the blood contains black pigment either floating freely or imbedded in the white blood corpuscles

melanagogue.definition: A medicine supposed to expel black bile or choler

melancholia.definition: A kind of mental unsoundness characterized by extreme depression of spirits, ill-grounded fears, delusions, and brooding over one particular subject or train of ideas

melancholian.definition: A person affected with melancholy; a melancholic

melancholic.definition: Given to melancholy; depressed; melancholy; dejected; unhappy
One affected with a gloomy state of mind
A gloomy state of mind; melancholy

melancholiness.definition: The state or quality of being melancholy

melancholist.definition: One affected with melancholy or dejection

melancholize.definition: To become gloomy or dejected in mind

melancholy.definition: Depression of spirits; a gloomy state continuing a considerable time; deep dejection; gloominess
Great and continued depression of spirits, amounting to mental unsoundness; melancholia
Depressed in spirits; dejected; gloomy dismal
Producing great evil and grief; causing dejection; calamitous; afflictive; as, a melancholy event
Somewhat deranged in mind; having the jugment impaired

melanconiaceae.definition: A family of fungi constituting the order Melanconiales

melanconiales.definition: The smallest of the three orders of Fungi Imperfecti, including those with no asci nor pycnidia, but as a rule having the spores in cavities without special walls.  They cause many of the plant diseases known as anthracnose

melanian.definition: One of a family of fresh-water pectinibranchiate mollusks, having a turret-shaped shell

melanic.definition: Of or pertaining to the black-haired races

melaniline.definition: A complex nitrogenous hydrocarbon obtained artificially (as by the action of cyanogen chloride on aniline) as a white, crystalline substance; -- called also diphenyl guanidin

melanin.definition: A black pigment found in the pigment-bearing cells of the skin (particularly in the skin of the negro), in the epithelial cells of the external layer of the retina (then called fuscin), in the outer layer of the choroid, and elsewhere. It is supposed to be derived from the decomposition of hemoglobin

melanism.definition: An undue development of dark-colored pigment in the skin or its appendages; -- the opposite of albinism
A disease; black jaundice. See Melaena
The character of having a high degree of pigmentation, as shown in dark skin, eyes, and hair

melanistic.definition: Affected with melanism; of the nature of melanism

melanochroi.definition: A group of the human race, including the dark whites

melanochroic.definition: Having a dark complexion; of or pertaining to the Melanochroi

melanochroite.definition: A mineral of a red, or brownish or yellowish red color.  It is a chromate of lead; -- called also phoenicocroite

melanocomous.definition: Having very dark or black hair; black-haired

melanoma.definition: A tumor containing dark pigment.  Such tumors are usually malignant and often fatal

melanorrhoea.definition: An East Indian genus of large trees. Melanorrhœa usitatissima is the lignum-vitae of Pegu (in Burma), and yields a valuable black varnish

melanoscope.definition: An instrument containing a combination of colored glasses such that they transmit only red light, so that objects of other colors, as green leaves, appear black when seen through it.  It is used for viewing colored flames, to detect the presence of potassium, lithium, etc., by the red light which they emit

melanosis.definition: The morbid deposition of black matter, often of a malignant character, causing pigmented tumors

melanosperm.definition: An alga of any kind that produces blackish spores, or seed dust.  The melanosperms include the rockweeds and all kinds of kelp

melanotype.definition: A positive picture produced with sensitized collodion on a smooth surface of black varnish, coating a thin plate of iron; also, the process of making such a picture

melanterite.definition: A hydrous sulphate of iron of a green color and vitreous luster; iron vitriol

melanure.definition: A small fish of the Mediterranean; a gilthead. See Gilthead (a)

melanuric.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid obtained by decomposition of melam, or of urea, as a white crystalline powder; -- called also melanurenic acid

melaphyre.definition: Any one of several dark-colored augitic, eruptive rocks allied to basalt

melasma.definition: A dark discoloration of the skin, usually local; as, Addison's melasma, or Addison's disease

melassic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid obtained from molasses or glucose, and probably identical with saccharic acid (also called D-glucaric acid or tetrahydroxyadipic acid). See Saccharic

melastoma.definition: A genus of evergreen tropical shrubs; -- so called from the black berries of some species, which stain the mouth

melastomaceous.definition: Belonging to the order of which Melastoma is the type

melatonin.definition: A hormone secreted by the pineal gland.  Chemically it is N-acety-5-methoxytryptamine.  Research has indicated that there are daily rhythms in secretion of melatonin, in particular due to the depressing effect on melatonin production by light received by the retina.  Conversely it appears that melatonin may influence the circadian rhythms of animals.  There is some experimental evidence that administration of melatonin may increase the amount of sleep in people with sleep disorders.  However, the evidence is not convincing and the effect is not profound.  Nevertheless, the deregulation of melatonin and its availability over-the-counter has led to many people taking melatonin to help sleep, without consulting a physician

melchite.definition: One of a sect, chiefly in Syria and Egypt, which acknowledges the authority of the pope, but adheres to the liturgy and ceremonies of the Eastern Church

meld.definition: In the game of pinochle, to declare or announce for a score; as, to meld a sequence
to mix together so that the components are indistinguishable
synonyms: Syn. -- blend, mix, conflate, commingle, immix, fuse, coalesce, combine, merge.

meld.definition: Any combination or score which may be declared, or melded, in pinochle
A form of rummy using two decks and four jokers; jokers and dueces are wild; the object is to meld groups of seven of the same rank

meleagrididae.definition: A natural family of fowls including the turkeys and some extinct forms

meleagrine.definition: Of or pertaining to the genus Meleagris

meleagris.definition: A genus of American gallinaceous birds, including the common turkey and the wild turkeys

melee.definition: A fight in which the combatants are mingled in one confused mass; a hand to hand conflict; an affray

A cavalry exercise in which two groups of riders try to cut paper plumes off the helmets of their opponents, the contest continuing until no member of one group retains his plume; -- sometimes called Balaklava mêlée

melene.definition: An unsaturated hydrocarbon, C30H60, of the ethylene series, obtained from beeswax as a white, scaly, crystalline wax; -- called also melissene, and melissylene

melenite.definition: An explosive of great destructive power; -- so called from its color, which resembles honey

melezitose.definition: A variety of sugar, isomeric with sucrose, extracted from the manna of the larch (Larix)

meliaceous.definition: Pertaining to a natural order (Meliacae) of plants of which the genus Melia is the type. It includes the mahogany and the Spanish cedar

melic.definition: Of or pertaining to song; lyric; tuneful

melic grass.definition: A genus of grasses (Melica) of little agricultural importance

melicerous.definition: Consisting of or containing matter like honey; -- said of certain encysted tumors

melilite.definition: A mineral occurring in small yellow crystals, found in the lavas (melilite basalt) of Vesuvius, and elsewhere

melilot.definition: Any species of Melilotus, a genus of leguminous herbs having a vanillalike odor; sweet clover; hart's clover. The blue melilot (Melilotus caerulea) is used in Switzerland to give color and flavor to sapsago cheese

melilotic.definition: Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, sweet clover or melilot; specifically, designating an acid of the aromatic series, obtained from melilot as a white crystalline substance

melinae.definition: A subdivision of mammals not used in some classifications; it includes the badgers

melinite.definition: A high explosive similar to lyddite, consisting principally of picric acid, used in the French military service

meliorate.definition: To make better; to improve; to ameliorate; to soften; to make more tolerable

melioration.definition: The act or operation of meliorating, or the state of being meliorated; improvement

meliorism.definition: The doctrine that there is a tendency throughout nature toward improvement

meliority.definition: The state or quality of being better; melioration

meliphagan.definition: Any bird of the genus Meliphaga and allied genera; a honey eater; -- called also meliphagidan

melisma.definition: A piece of melody; a song or tune, -- as opposed to recitative or musical declamation

melissa.definition: A genus of labiate herbs, including the balm, or bee balm (Melissa officinalis)

melissic.definition: Pertaining to, or derived from, beeswax; specif., denoting an acid obtained by oxidation of myricin

melitose.definition: A variety of sugar isomeric with sucrose, extracted from cotton seeds and from the so-called Australian manna (a secretion of certain species of Eucalyptus)

mellification.definition: The making or production of honey

mellifluence.definition: A flow of sweetness, or a sweet, smooth flow

mellifluent.definition: Flowing as with honey; smooth; mellifluous

mellifluous.definition: Flowing as with honey; smooth; flowing sweetly or smoothly; as, a mellifluous voice

mellite.definition: A mineral of a honey color, found in brown coal, and partly the result of vegetable decomposition; honeystone.  It is a mellitate of alumina

mellitic.definition: Containing saccharine matter; marked by saccharine secretions; as, mellitic diabetes

mellone.definition: A yellow powder, C6H3N9, obtained from certain sulphocyanates.  It has acid properties and forms compounds called mellonides

mellow.definition: Soft or tender by reason of ripeness; having a tender pulp; as, a mellow apple
Easily worked or penetrated; not hard or rigid; as, a mellow soil
Well matured; softened by years; genial; jovial
To become mellow; as, ripe fruit soon mellows

mellowed.definition: having a mild and pleasing flavor through proper aging
having attained to kindliness or gentleness through age and experience; -- of people

mellowing.definition: The act or process of acquiring desirable qualities by being left undisturbed for some time

mellowness.definition: Quality or state of being mellow

melluco.definition: A climbing plant (Ullucus officinalis) of the Andes, having tuberous roots which are used as a substitute for potatoes

melodeon.definition: A kind of small reed organ; -- a portable form of the seraphine

melodic.definition: Of the nature of melody; relating to, containing, or made up of, melody; melodious

melodics.definition: The branch of musical science which treats of the pitch of tones, and of the laws of melody

melodiograph.definition: A contrivance for preserving a record of music, by recording the action of the keys of a musical instrument when played upon

melodious.definition: Containing, or producing, melody; musical; agreeable to the ear by a sweet succession of sounds; as, a melodious voice

melodist.definition: A composer or singer of melodies

melodize.definition: To make melodious; to form into, or set to, melody
To make melody; to compose melodies; to harmonize

melodrama.definition: Formerly, a kind of drama having a musical accompaniment to intensify the effect of certain scenes.  Now, a drama abounding in romantic sentiment and agonizing situations, with a musical accompaniment only in parts which are especially thrilling or pathetic.  In opera, a passage in which the orchestra plays a somewhat descriptive accompaniment, while the actor speaks; as, the melodrama in the gravedigging scene of Beethoven's “Fidelio”

melodramatic.definition: Of or pertaining to melodrama; like or suitable to a melodrama; unnatural in situation or action

melodramatist.definition: One who acts in, or writes, melodramas

melody.definition: A sweet or agreeable succession of sounds

A rhythmical succession of single tones, ranging for the most part within a given key, and so related together as to form a musical whole, having the unity of what is technically called a musical thought, at once pleasing to the ear and characteristic in expression
The air or tune of a musical piece

meloe.definition: A genus of beetles without wings, but having short oval elytra; the oil beetles.  These beetles are sometimes used instead of cantharides for raising blisters. See Oil beetle, under Oil

meloid.definition: A beetle belongoing to the family Meloidae

meloidae.definition: A natural family of insects comprising the blister beetles

melolonthidae.definition: A natural subfamily of beetles, considered a separate family in some classification systems

melolonthidian.definition: A beetle of the genus Melolontha, and allied genera.  See May beetle, under May

melon.definition: The juicy fruit of certain cucurbitaceous plants, as the muskmelon, watermelon, and citron melon; also, the plant that produces the fruit
A large, ornamental, marine, univalve shell of the genus Melo

melopiano.definition: A piano having a mechanical attachment which enables the player to prolong the notes at will

meloplastic.definition: Of or pertaining to meloplasty, or the artificial formation of a new cheek

meloplasty.definition: The process of restoring a cheek which has been destroyed wholly or in part

melopoeia.definition: The art of forming melody; melody; -- now often used for a melodic passage, rather than a complete melody

melosa.definition: A South American herb (Madia sativa) with sticky glandular foliage; it is a source of madia oil
synonyms: Syn. -- Chile tarweed, madia oil plant, Madia sativa.

melospiza.definition: A genus of American song sparrows and swamp sparrows

melotype.definition: A picture produced by a process in which development after exposure may be deferred indefinitely, so as to permit transportation of exposed plates; also, the process itself

melt.definition: To reduce from a solid to a liquid state, as by heat; to liquefy; as, to melt wax, tallow, or lead; to melt ice or snow
To soften, as by a warming or kindly influence; to relax; to render gentle or susceptible to mild influences; sometimes, in a bad sense, to take away the firmness of; to weaken
To be changed from a solid to a liquid state under the influence of heat; as, butter and wax melt at moderate temperatures
To dissolve; as, sugar melts in the mouth
To be softened; to become tender, mild, or gentle; also, to be weakened or subdued, as by fear
To lose distinct form or outline; to blend.  See fondue
To disappear by being dispersed or dissipated; as, the fog melts away

melter.definition: One who, or that which, melts

melting.definition: Liquefaction; the act of causing (something) to melt, or the process of becoming melted
Causing to melt; becoming melted; -- used literally or figuratively; as, a melting heat; a melting appeal; a melting mood

melting pot.definition: A vessel in which anything is melted; a crucible

A place where people of different backgrounds become similar in culture.  The United States has often been referred to as a melting pot, though the differences in cultures of recently arrived immigrants persists beyond the generation of immigrants

melton.definition: A kind of stout woolen cloth with unfinished face and without raised nap. A commoner variety has a cotton warp

melungeon.definition: One of a mixed white and Indian people living in parts of Tennessee and the Carolinas.  They are descendants of early intermixtures of white settlers with natives.  In North Carolina the Croatan Indians, regarded as descended from Raleigh's lost colony of Croatan, formerly classed with negroes, are now legally recognized as distinct

melursus.definition: A genus of mammals including the sloth bears; in some classifications not a separate genus from Ursus

melville.definition: Herman Melville, American novelist, author of Moby Dick; b. 1819, d. 1891

mem.definition: the 13th letter of the Hebrew alphabet

member.definition: To remember; to cause to remember; to mention
A part of an animal capable of performing a distinct office; an organ; a limb
A part of a whole; an independent constituent of a body

membered.definition: Having limbs; -- chiefly used in composition
Having legs of a different tincture from that of the body; -- said of a bird in heraldic representations

membership.definition: The state of being a member
The collective body of members, as of a society

membranaceous.definition: Thin and rather soft or pliable, as the leaves of the rose, peach tree, and aspen poplar

membrane.definition: A thin layer or fold of tissue, usually supported by a fibrous network, serving to cover or line some part or organ, and often secreting or absorbing certain fluids

membraniform.definition: Having the form of a membrane or of parchment

membranology.definition: The science which treats of membranes

membranous.definition: Pertaining to, consisting of, or resembling, membrane; as, a membranous covering or lining

memento.definition: A hint, suggestion, token, or memorial, to awaken memory; that which reminds or recalls to memory; a souvenir

memento mori.definition: Lit., remember to die, i.e., that you must die; a warning to be prepared for death; an object, as a death's-head or a personal ornament, usually emblematic, used as a reminder of death

meminna.definition: A small deerlet, or chevrotain, of India

memnon.definition: A celebrated Egyptian statue near Thebes, said to have the property of emitting a harplike sound at sunrise

memoir.definition: A memorial account; a history composed from personal experience and memory; an account of transactions or events (usually written in familiar style) as they are remembered by the writer. See History, 2
A memorial of any individual; a biography; often, a biography written without special regard to method and completeness
An account of something deemed noteworthy; an essay; a record of investigations of any subject; the journals and proceedings of a society

memorabilia.definition: Things remarkable and worthy of remembrance or record; also, the record of them

memorability.definition: The quality or state of being memorable

memorable.definition: Worthy to be remembered; very important or remarkable

memorandum.definition: A record of something which it is desired to remember; a note to help the memory
A brief or informal note in writing of some transaction, or an outline of an intended instrument; an instrument drawn up in a brief and compendious form

memorial.definition: Serving to preserve remembrance; commemorative; as, a memorial building
Contained in memory; as, a memorial possession
Anything intended to preserve the memory of a person or event; something which serves to keep something else in remembrance; a monument
A written representation of facts, addressed to the government, or to some branch of it, or to a society, etc., -- often accompanied with a petition
A species of informal state paper, much used in negotiation

memorial day.definition: A day, originally May 30, appointed for commemorating, by decorating their graves with flowers, by patriotic exercises, etc., the dead soldiers and sailors who served the Civil War (1861-65) in the United States; Also called Decoration Day. It is a legal holiday in most of the States. In the Southern States, the Confederate Memorial Day is: May 30 in Virginia; April 26 in Alabama, Florida, Georgia, and Mississippi; May 10 in North Carolina and South Carolina; the second Friday in May in Tennessee; June 3 in Louisiana
A day designated for commemoration of all of the war dead of the United States, clebrated on the last Monday in May in most states.  It supersedes the original Memorial Day celebrated May 30th

memorial rose.definition: A Japanese evergreen rose (Rosa wichuraiana) with creeping branches, shining leaves, and single white flowers. It is often planted in cemeteries

memorialist.definition: One who writes or signs a memorial

memorialize.definition: To address or petition by a memorial; to present a memorial to; as, to memorialize the legislature

memorializer.definition: One who petitions by a memorial

memorist.definition: One who, or that which, causes to be remembered

memorize.definition: To cause to be remembered ; hence, to record
To commit to memory; to learn by heart

memorizer.definition: A person who learns by rote

memory.definition: The faculty of the mind by which it retains the knowledge of previous thoughts, impressions, or events
The reach and positiveness with which a person can remember; the strength and trustworthiness of one's power to reach and represent or to recall the past; as, his memory was never wrong
The actual and distinct retention and recognition of past ideas in the mind; remembrance; as, in memory of youth; memories of foreign lands
The time within which past events can be or are remembered; as, within the memory of man
Something, or an aggregate of things, remembered; hence, character, conduct, etc., as preserved in remembrance, history, or tradition; posthumous fame; as, the war became only a memory

memphian.definition: Of or pertaining to the ancient city of Memphis in Egypt; hence, Egyptian; as, Memphian darkness
Of or pertaining to the city of Memphis in Tennessee
A native or resident of the city of Memphis in Tennessee

memsahib.definition: Lady; mistress; -- used by Hindustani-speaking natives in India in addressing European women

men.definition: A man; one; -- used with a verb in the singular, and corresponding to the present indefinite one or they

men-pleaser.definition: One whose motive is to please men or the world, rather than God

menaccanite.definition: An iron-black or steel-gray mineral, consisting chiefly of the oxides of iron and titanium. It is commonly massive, but occurs also in rhombohedral crystals.  Called also titanic iron ore, and ilmenite

menace.definition: The show of an intention to inflict evil; a threat or threatening; indication of a probable evil or catastrophe to come

To express or show an intention to inflict, or to hold out a prospect of inflicting, evil or injury upon; to threaten; -- usually followed by with before the harm threatened; as, to menace a country with war
To threaten, as an evil to be inflicted
To act in threatening manner; to wear a threatening aspect

menage.definition: A collection of animals; a menagerie
A social group living together; a household

menage-a-trois.definition: A relationship involving three people, especially one in which three people live together and have sexual relations, such as a married couple and a lover of one of the pair
A single sexual encounter in which three people participate
An unlikely situation in which a group of three people not normally associated with each other participate in an activity together

menagerie.definition: A place where animals are kept and trained
A collection of wild or exotic animals, kept for exhibition

menaion.definition: A work of twelve volumes, each containing the offices in the Greek Church for a month; also, each volume of the same

mend.definition: To repair, as anything that is torn, broken, defaced, decayed, or the like; to restore from partial decay, injury, or defacement; to patch up; to put in shape or order again; to re-create; as, to mend a garment or a machine
To alter for the better; to set right; to reform; hence, to quicken; as, to mend one's manners or pace
To help, to advance, to further; to add to
To grow better; to advance to a better state; to become improved; to recover; to heal

mendacious.definition: Given to deception or falsehood; lying; as, a mendacious person
False; counterfeit; containing falsehood; as, a mendacious statement

mendacity.definition: The quality or state of being mendacious; a habit of lying

mendel.definition: Gregor Johann Mendel, founder of the science of genetics (1822-1884); Gregor Mendel

mendel's law.definition: A principle governing the inheritance of many characters in animals and plants, discovered by Gregor J. Mendel (Austrian Augustinian abbot, 1822-84) in breeding experiments with peas.  He showed that the height, color, and other characters depend on the presence of determinating factors behaving as units.  In any given germ cell each of these is either present or absent

mendelevium.definition: an unstable radioactive element discovered in 1955 and produced artificially only in very small quantities; symbol Md (also Mv).  It is a transuranic element with atomic number 101.  Isotopes 255, 256, 257, and 258 have been prepared.  Md258, the longest-lived, has a half-life of two months

mendelian.definition: Pert. to Mendel, or to Mendel's law; as, Mendelian inheritance
Behaving or being in accordance with Mendel's laws of inheritance; -- said of the distribution of inherited characteristics and of traits thus distributed

mendelian character.definition: A character which obeys Mendel's law in regard to its hereditary transmission

mendicancy.definition: The condition of being mendicant; beggary; begging

mendicant.definition: Practicing beggary; begging; living on alms; as, mendicant friars
A beggar; esp., one who makes a business of begging; specifically, a begging friar

mendication.definition: The act or practice of begging; beggary; mendicancy

mendicity.definition: The practice of begging; the life of a beggar; mendicancy

menhaden.definition: An American marine fish (Brevoortia tyrannus) of the Herring family (Clupeidae), chiefly valuable for its oil and as a component of fertilizers; -- called also mossbunker, bony fish, chebog, pogy, hardhead, whitefish, etc

menhir.definition: A large stone set upright in olden times as a memorial or monument.  Many, of unknown date, are found in Brittany and throughout Northern Europe

menial.definition: Belonging to a retinue or train of servants; performing servile office; serving
Pertaining to servants, esp. domestic servants; servile; low; mean; as, menial tasks
A domestic servant or retainer, esp. one of humble rank; one employed in low or servile offices
A person of a servile character or disposition

meniere's disease.definition: A disease characterized by deafness and vertigo, resulting in incoordination of movement.  It is supposed to depend upon a morbid condition of the semicircular canals of the internal ear.  Named after Ménière, a French physician

meningeal.definition: Of or pertaining to the meninges

meninges.definition: The three membranes that envelop the brain and spinal cord; the pia mater, dura mater, and arachnoid membrane

meningitis.definition: Inflammation of the membranes of the brain or spinal cord

meniscal.definition: Pertaining to, or having the form of, a meniscus

meniscus.definition: A lens convex on one side and concave on the other
An interarticular synovial cartilage or membrane; esp., one of the intervertebral synovial disks in some parts of the vertebral column of birds

menispermaceous.definition: Pertaining to a natural order (Menispermaceae) of climbing plants of which moonseed (Menispermum) is the type

menispermic.definition: Pertaining to, or obtained from, moonseed (Menispermum), or other plants of the same family, as the Anamirta Cocculus

menispermine.definition: An alkaloid distinct from picrotoxin and obtained from the cocculus indicus (the fruit of Anamirta Cocculus, formerly Menispermum Cocculus) as a white, crystalline, tasteless powder; -- called also menispermina

mennonist.definition: One of a small denomination of Christians, so called from Menno Simons of Friesland, their founder.  They believe that the New Testament is the only rule of faith, that there is no original sin, that infants should not be baptized, and that Christians ought not to take oath, hold office, or render military service

menobranch.definition: A large aquatic American salamander of the genus Necturus, having permanent external gills

menologium.definition: A brief calendar of the lives of the saints for each day in the year, or a simple remembrance of those whose lives are not written

menopause.definition: The period of natural cessation of menstruation. See Change of life, under Change

mensal.definition: Belonging to the table; transacted at table; as, mensal conversation
Occurring once in a month; monthly

menses.definition: The catamenial or menstrual discharge, a periodic flow of blood or bloody fluid from the uterus or female generative organs

menstrual.definition: Recurring once a month; monthly; gone through in a month; as, the menstrual revolution of the moon; pertaining to monthly changes; as, the menstrual equation of the sun's place
Of or pertaining to the menses; as, menstrual discharges; the menstrual period
Of or pertaining to a menstruum

menstruant.definition: Subject to monthly flowing or menses

menstruate.definition: To discharge the menses; to have the catamenial flow

menstruating.definition: discharging menstrual fluid; -- of women during their menstrual period

menstruation.definition: The discharge of the menses; also, the state or the period of menstruating

menstruous.definition: Having the monthly flow or discharge; menstruating
Of or pertaining to the monthly flow; catamenial

menstruum.definition: Any substance which dissolves a solid body; a solvent

mensurableness.definition: The quality or state of being mensurable; measurableness

mensuration.definition: The act, process, or art, of measuring
That branch of applied geometry which gives rules for finding the length of lines, the areas of surfaces, or the volumes of solids, from certain simple data of lines and angles

mental.definition: Of or pertaining to the chin; genian; as, the mental nerve; the mental region
A plate or scale covering the mentum or chin of a fish or reptile
Of or pertaining to the mind; intellectual; as, mental faculties; mental operations, conditions, or exercise

mentalism.definition: a doctrine that mind is the only true reality and that objects exist only as aspects of the mind's awareness
Any theory of psychology that accepts introspective data about the functioning of the mind as a valid object of study; contrasted to behaviorism

mentally.definition: In the mind; in thought or meditation; intellectually; in idea

mentation.definition: the process of thinking (especially thinking carefully); mental activity

mentha.definition: A widely distributed genus of fragrant herbs, including the peppermint, spearmint, etc. The plants have small flowers, usually arranged in dense axillary clusters

menthene.definition: A colorless liquid hydrocarbon resembling oil of turpentine, obtained by dehydrating menthol. It has an agreeable odor and a cooling taste

menthol.definition: A white, crystalline, aromatic substance (C10H20O) resembling camphor, extracted from oil of peppermint (Mentha); -- called also mint camphor or peppermint camphor.  It has the peculiar effect on skin and membranes of making them feel cool, and is used in liqueurs, confections, cigarettes, cough drops and perfumes, among other things

menthyl.definition: A compound radical forming the base of menthol

menticirrhus.definition: A genus of kingfishes, including the whiting

menticultural.definition: Of or pertaining to mental culture; serving to improve or strengthen the mind

mention.definition: A speaking or notice of anything, -- usually in a brief or cursory manner. Used especially in the phrase to make mention of
To make mention of; to speak briefly of; to name

mentomeckelian.definition: Of or pertaining to the chin and lower jaw

mentor.definition: A wise and faithful counselor or monitor

mentum.definition: The front median plate of the labium in insects. See Labium

mentzelia.definition: A genus of bristly herbs or subshrubs of Western America lacking stinging hairs

menu.definition: The details of a banquet; a list of the dishes served at a meal, whether or not one has a choice
Any list of objects, activities, etc. from which to choose; a selection of alternatives
A list of dishes form which to choose at a restaurant; a bill of fare

A list displayed on the computer screen, by which a program provides the user with different options for processing by the program.  It usually includes a mechanism, such as pointing by a mouse or selection by arrow keys, to select the desired option from those on the list.  Depending on how the menu is displayed, it may be a pop-up menu or pull-down menu

menurae.definition: A suborder of birds including lyrebirds and scrubbirds

menuridae.definition: A natural family of birds including the lyrebirds

menyanthes.definition: The type genus of the Menyanthaceae, having only one species: the bogbeans

menziesia.definition: A genus of deciduous shrubs of North America and eastern Asia

mepacrine.definition: Quinacrine, a drug once used to treat malaria; Atabrine is a trademark

meperidine.definition: A synthetic narcotic drug used as a sedative; Demerol is the trademark of a brand of meperidine

mephistophelean.definition: Pertaining to, or resembling, the devil Mephistopheles, “a crafty, scoffing, relentless fiend;” devilish in character or aspect; crafty; showing cunning or ingenuity or wickedness; as, a mephistophelean glint in his eye

mephistopheles.definition: A familiar spirit mentioned in the old legend of Sir John Faustus, and a principal agent in Marlowe's play Dr. Faustus and in Goethe's Faust.  In medieval demonology, he was one of the seven chief devils

mephitic.definition: Tending to destroy life; poisonous; noxious; as, mephitic exhalations; mephitic regions
Offensive to the smell; as, mephitic odors

mephitinae.definition: A subfamily of mammals including the skunks; it is a subdivision not used in some classifications

mephitis.definition: Noxious, pestilential, or foul exhalations from decomposing substances, filth, or other source
A genus of mammals, including the skunks

meracious.definition: Being without mixture or adulteration; hence, strong; racy

merbromine.definition: A mercurial compound applied topically as an antiseptic; Mercurochrome is the trademark

mercable.definition: Capable of being bought or sold

mercantile.definition: Of or pertaining to merchants, or the business of merchants; having to do with trade, or the buying and selling of commodities; commercial

mercaptal.definition: Any one of a series of compounds of mercaptans with aldehydes

mercaptan.definition: Any one of series of compounds having an -SH radical attached to a carbon atom, also considered as hydrosulphides of alcohol radicals, in composition resembling the alcohols, but containing sulphur in place of oxygen, and hence called also the sulphur alcohols.  In general, they are colorless liquids having a strong, repulsive, garlic odor.  The name is specifically applied to ethyl mercaptan, C2H5SH.  So called from its avidity for mercury, and other metals

mercaptide.definition: A compound of mercaptan formed by replacing its sulphur hydrogen by a metal; as, potassium mercaptide, C2H5SK

merce.definition: To subject to fine or amercement; to mulct; to amerce

mercenariness.definition: The quality or state of being mercenary; venality

mercenary.definition: Acting for reward; serving for pay; paid; hired; hireling; venal; as, mercenary soldiers
Moved primarily by considerations of pay or profit; greedy of gain; sordid; selfish
One who is hired; a hireling; especially, a soldier hired into foreign service

mercer.definition: Originally, a dealer in any kind of goods or wares; now restricted to a dealer in textile fabrics, as silks or woolens

mercerize.definition: To treat (cotton fiber or fabrics) with a solution of caustic alkali.  Such treatment causes the fiber to shrink in length and become stronger and more receptive of dyes. If the yarn or cloth is kept under tension during the process, it assumes a silky luster

mercery.definition: The trade of mercers; the goods in which a mercer deals

merchandisable.definition: Such as can be used or transferred as merchandise

merchandise.definition: The objects of commerce; whatever is usually bought or sold in trade, or market, or by merchants; wares; goods; commodities
The act or business of trading; trade; traffic
To trade; to carry on commerce
To make merchandise of; to buy and sell

merchandising.definition: The activities associated with selling products, such as identification of the market{7}, advertising at the right time in the right media{7}, and creating attractive packaging and displays; also, the study of the best methods to accomplish such goals

merchant.definition: One who traffics on a large scale, especially with foreign countries; a trafficker; a trader
One who keeps a store or shop for the sale of goods; a shopkeeper
Of, pertaining to, or employed in, trade or merchandise; as, the merchant service
To be a merchant; to trade

merchant marine.definition: The ships owned by nationals of a particular country that are engaged in civilian commerce; also, the personnel operating those vessels.  Distinguished from the navy, which contains the vessels of war

merchantable.definition: Fit for market; such as is usually sold in market, or such as will bring the ordinary price; as, merchantable wheat; sometimes, a technical designation for a particular kind or class

merchantly.definition: Merchantlike; suitable to the character or business of a merchant

merchantman.definition: A trading vessel; a ship employed in the transportation of goods, as, distinguished from a man-of-war

merchantry.definition: The body of merchants taken collectively; as, the merchantry of a country
The business of a merchant; merchandise

merciful.definition: Full of mercy; having or exercising mercy; disposed to pity and spare offenders; unwilling to punish.  Opposite of merciless

merciless.definition: Destitute of mercy; cruel; unsparing; -- said of animate beings, and also, figuratively, of things; as, a merciless tyrant; merciless waves

mercurammonium.definition: A radical regarded as derived from ammonium by the substitution of mercury for a portion of the hydrogen

mercurial.definition: Having the qualities fabled to belong to the god Mercury; swift; active; sprightly; fickle; volatile; changeable; as, a mercurial youth; a mercurial temperament
Having the form or image of Mercury; -- applied to ancient guideposts
Of or pertaining to Mercury as the god of trade; hence, money-making; crafty
Of or pertaining to, or containing, mercury; as, mercurial preparations, barometer. See Mercury, 2
Caused by the use of mercury; as, mercurial sore mouth

mercurialism.definition: The syndrome produced by poisoning due to exposure to mercury, it fumes, or its compounds; mercury poisoning.  Such exposure may occur in mining or smelting, or in using mercurial compounds

mercurialist.definition: One under the influence of Mercury; one resembling Mercury in character
A physician who uses much mercury, in any of its forms, in his practice

mercurialize.definition: To treat with mercury; to expose to the vapor of mercury
To be sprightly, fantastic, or capricious

mercuric.definition: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, mercury; containing mercury; -- said of those compounds of mercury into which this element enters in its lowest proportion

mercurification.definition: The process or operation of obtaining the mercury, in its fluid form, from mercuric minerals
The act or process of compounding, or the state of being compounded, with mercury

mercurify.definition: To obtain mercury from, as mercuric minerals, which may be done by any application of intense heat that expels the mercury in fumes, which are afterward condensed
To combine or mingle mercury with; to impregnate with mercury; to mercurialize

mercurism.definition: A communication of news; an announcement

mercurous.definition: Of, pertaining to, or derived from, mercury; containing mercury; -- said of those compounds of mercury in which it is present in its highest proportion

mercury.definition: A Latin god of commerce and gain; -- treated by the poets as identical with the Greek Hermes, messenger of the gods, conductor of souls to the lower world, and god of eloquence

A metallic element mostly obtained by reduction from cinnabar, one of its ores.  It is a heavy, opaque, glistening liquid (commonly called quicksilver), and is used in barometers, thermometers, etc.  Specific gravity 13.6.  Symbol Hg (Hydrargyrum).  Atomic weight 199.8.  Mercury has a molecule which consists of only one atom.  It was named by the alchemists after the god Mercury, and designated by his symbol, &mercury_
One of the planets of the solar system, being the one nearest the sun, from which its mean distance is about 36,000,000 miles. Its period is 88 days, and its diameter 3,000 miles
A carrier of tidings; a newsboy; a messenger; hence, also, a newspaper
Sprightly or mercurial quality; spirit; mutability; fickleness
A plant (Mercurialis annua), of the Spurge family, the leaves of which are sometimes used for spinach, in Europe
To wash with a preparation of mercury

mercury bichloride.definition: the compound (HgCl2) consisting of two atoms of chlorine united with one atom of mercury.   Also called bichloride of mercury, mercuric chloride, corrosive sublimate, and mercury perchloride.  It is used as “a topical antiseptic and disinfectant for inanimate objects”

mercury fulminate.definition: The mercury salt of fulminic acid (Hg(CNO)2), called also fulminate of mercury.  It is an explosive compound prepared as gray crystals, and is used primarily in detonators for detonating high explosives, such as dynamite or TNT.  It is sensitive to shock and may be detonated by a blow

mercy.definition: Forbearance to inflict harm under circumstances of provocation, when one has the power to inflict it; compassionate treatment of an offender or adversary; clemency
Compassionate treatment of the unfortunate and helpless; sometimes, favor, beneficence
Disposition to exercise compassion or favor; pity; compassion; willingness to spare or to help
A blessing regarded as a manifestation of compassion or favor

mere.definition: Only this, and nothing else; such, and no more; simple; bare; as, a mere boy; a mere form

merely.definition: Not otherwise than; simply; barely; only

meresman.definition: An officer who ascertains meres or boundaries

merestead.definition: The land within the boundaries of a farm; a farmstead or farm

merestone.definition: A stone designating a limit or boundary; a landmark

meretricious.definition: Of or pertaining to prostitutes; having to do with harlots; lustful; as, meretricious traffic
Resembling the arts of a harlot; alluring by false show; gaudily and deceitfully ornamental; tawdry; as, meretricious dress or ornaments
Deceptive or based on deception; seeming plausible, but based on pretense or insincerity; deceptive; misleading; insincere; specious; as, meretricious arguments

meretriciousness.definition: an appearance of truth that is false or deceptive; seeming plausibility

synonyms: Syn. -- flashiness, garishness, gaudiness, loudness, tawdriness, glitz.

merganser.definition: Any bird of the genus Mergus (Merganser), and allied genera of the subfamily Merginae.  They are allied to the ducks, but have a sharply serrated bill, eat fish, and dive for food.  Also called fish duck

merge.definition: To cause to be swallowed up; to immerse; to sink; to absorb
To be sunk, swallowed up, or lost

merged.definition: formed or united into a whole; -- of formerly separate objects, groups, etc

merger.definition: One who, or that which, merges
An absorption of one estate, or one contract, in another, or of a minor offense in a greater
The combining of two groups into a unified single group under a single leadership, with voluntary participation by the leaders or management of both groups

The combining of two commercial enterprises into a unified single enterprise under a single management, with voluntary participation by both parties; as, the merger of Daimler-Benz and Chrysler into Daimler-Chrysler created a powerful competitor in the automobile manufacturing industry.  Compare acquisition and takeover

merging.definition: The act or process of joining together into one entity

mergus.definition: A genus of ducks consisting of mergansers

mericarp.definition: One carpel of an umbelliferous fruit. See Cremocarp

meride.definition: A permanent colony of cells or plastids which may remain isolated, like Rotifer, or may multiply by gemmation to form higher aggregates, termed zoides

meridian.definition: Being at, or pertaining to, midday; belonging to, or passing through, the highest point attained by the sun in his diurnal course
Pertaining to the highest point or culmination; as, meridian splendor
Hence: The highest point, as of success, prosperity, or the like; culmination
A great circle of the sphere passing through the poles of the heavens and the zenith of a given place. It is crossed by the sun at midday
A great circle on the surface of the earth, passing through the poles and any given place; also, the half of such a circle included between the poles

meridional.definition: Of or pertaining to the meridian
Having a southern aspect; southern; southerly

meridionality.definition: The state of being in the meridian
Position in the south; aspect toward the south

meridionally.definition: In the direction of the meridian

merils.definition: A boy's play, called also fivepenny morris. See Morris

meringue.definition: A delicate pastry made of powdered sugar and the whites of eggs whipped up, -- with jam or cream added

merino.definition: Of or pertaining to a variety of sheep with very fine wool, originally bred in Spain
Made of the wool of the merino sheep
A breed of sheep originally from Spain, noted for the fineness of its wool
A fine fabric of merino wool

merismatic.definition: Dividing into cells or segments; characterized by separation into two or more parts or sections by the formation of internal partitions; as, merismatic growth, where one cell divides into many

meristem.definition: A tissue of growing cells, or cells capable of further division

merit.definition: The quality or state of deserving well or ill; desert
The quality or state of deserving well; worth; excellence
Reward deserved; any mark or token of excellence or approbation; as, his teacher gave him ten merits
To earn by service or performance; to have a right to claim as reward; to deserve; sometimes, to deserve in a bad sense; as, to merit punishment
To acquire desert; to gain value; to receive benefit; to profit

meritmonger.definition: One who depends on merit for salvation

meritocracy.definition: A form of social system in which power goes to those with superior intellects
The belief that rulers should be chosen for their superior abilities and not because of their wealth or birth

meritocratic.definition: Of or pertaining to meritocracy; as, meritocratic society

meritorious.definition: Possessing merit; deserving of reward or honor; worthy of recompense; valuable

meritot.definition: A play of children, in swinging on ropes, or the like, till they are dizzy

merk.definition: An old Scotch silver coin; a mark or marc

merkin.definition: Originally, a wig; afterwards, a mop for cleaning cannon
A patch of false hair, or something resembling hair, worn on a string over the female pudenda; -- used by stripteasers
The hair on the female pubic area

merlin.definition: A small European falcon (Falco columbarius, syn. Falco lithofalco, or Falco aesalon).  In North America called also pigeon hawk

merlon.definition: One of the solid parts of a battlemented parapet; a battlement. See Illust. of Battlement

merluce.definition: The European hake; -- called also herring hake and sea pike

mermaid.definition: A fabled marine creature, typically represented as having the upper part like that of a woman, and the lower like a fish; a sea nymph, sea woman, or woman fish

merman.definition: The male corresponding to mermaid; a sea man, or man fish

mero.definition: Any of several large groupers of warm seas, esp. the guasa (Epinephelus guaza), the red grouper (Epinephelus morio), the black grouper (Epinephelus nigritas), distinguished as Me"ro de lo al"to (&unr_;), and a species called also rock hind, distinguished as Me"ro ca*brol"la (&unr_;)

meroblast.definition: An ovum, as that of a mammal, only partially composed of germinal matter, that is, consisting of both a germinal portion and an albuminous or nutritive one; -- opposed to holoblast

meroblastic.definition: Consisting only in part of germinal matter; characterized by partial segmentation only; as, meroblastic ova, in which a portion of the yolk only undergoes fission; meroblastic segmentation; -- opposed to holoblastic

merocele.definition: Hernia in the thigh; femoral hernia

meroistic.definition: Applied to the ovaries of insects when they secrete vitelligenous cells, as well as ova

meropidan.definition: One of a family of birds (Meropidae), including the bee-eaters

meropodite.definition: The fourth joint of a typical appendage of Crustacea

meros.definition: The plain surface between the channels of a triglyph
The proximal segment of the hind limb; the thigh

merosome.definition: One of the serial segments, or metameres, of which the bodies of vertebrate and articulate animals are composed

merostomata.definition: A class of Arthropoda, allied to the Crustacea.  It includes the trilobites, Eurypteroidea, and Limuloidea.  All are extinct except the horseshoe crabs (Limulus) of the last group. See Limulus

merovingian.definition: Of or pertaining to the first Frankish dynasty in Gaul or France

merozoite.definition: A form of spore, usually elongate or falciform, and somewhat amoeboid, produced by segmentation of the schizonts of certain Sporozoa, as the malaria parasite

merrily.definition: In a merry manner; with mirth; with gayety and laughter; jovially. See Mirth, and Merry

merriness.definition: The quality or state of being merry; merriment; mirth; gayety, with laughter

merry.definition: Laughingly gay; overflowing with good humor and good spirits; jovial; inclined to laughter or play; sportive
Causing laughter, mirth, gladness, or delight; as, a merry jest
A kind of wild red cherry

merry-andrew.definition: One whose business is to make sport for others; a buffoon; a zany; especially, one who attends a mountebank or quack doctor

merry-go-round.definition: Any revolving contrivance for affording amusement; esp., a group of seats in the shape of hobbyhorses or other fanciful animals, arranged in a circle on a platform that is rotated by a mechanical drive, often to the accompaniment of music; the seats often move up and down in synchrony with the rotation; -- called also carousel.  It is employed primarily for the amusement of children, and is typically found at an amusement park

merrymake.definition: Mirth; frolic; a meeting for mirth; a festival
To make merry; to be jolly; to feast

merrymaker.definition: One who makes merriment or indulges in conviviality; a jovial comrade

merrymaking.definition: Making or producing mirth; convivial; jolly
The act of making merry; conviviality; merriment; jollity

merrythought.definition: The forked bone of a fowl's breast; -- called also wishbone. See Furculum

merulidan.definition: A bird of the Thrush family

mesa.definition: A high tableland; a plateau on a hill

mesaconic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, one of several isomeric acids obtained from citric acid

mesalliance.definition: A marriage with a person of inferior social position; a misalliance

mesamoeboid.definition: One of a class of independent, isolated cells found in the mesoderm, while the germ layers are undergoing differentiation

mesaticephalic.definition: Having the ratio of the length to the breadth of the cranium a medium one; neither brachycephalic nor dolichocephalic

mescal.definition: A distilled liquor prepared in Mexico from a species of agave. See Agave

mesembryanthemum.definition: A genus of herbaceous or suffruticose plants, chiefly natives of South Africa.  The leaves are opposite, thick, and fleshy.  The flowers usually open about midday, whence the name

mesencephalic.definition: Of or pertaining to the mesencephalon or midbrain

mesencephalon.definition: The middle segment of the brain; the midbrain.  Sometimes abbreviated to mesen. See Brain

mesenchyma.definition: The part of the mesoblast which gives rise to the connective tissues and blood

mesenteron.definition: All that part of the alimentary canal which is developed from the primitive enteron and is lined with hypoblast. It is distinguished from the stomodaeum, a part at the anterior end of the canal, including the cavity of the mouth, and the proctodaeum, a part at the posterior end, which are formed by invagination and are lined with epiblast

mesentery.definition: The membranes, or one of the membranes (consisting of a fold of the peritoneum and inclosed tissues), which connect the intestines and their appendages with the dorsal wall of the abdominal cavity. The mesentery proper is connected with the jejunum and ilium, the other mesenteries being called mesocaecum, mesocolon, mesorectum, etc
One of the vertical muscular radiating partitions which divide the body cavity of Anthozoa into chambers

mesethmoid.definition: Of or pertaining to the middle of the ethmoid region or ethmoid bone

mesh.definition: The opening or space inclosed by the threads of a net between knot and knot, or the threads inclosing such a space; network; a net
The engagement of the teeth of wheels, or of a wheel and rack
To engage with each other, as the teeth of wheels

mesiad.definition: Toward, or on the side toward, the mesial plane; mesially; -- opposed to laterad

mesial.definition: Middle; median; in, or in the region of, the mesial plane; internal; -- opposed to lateral

mesially.definition: In, near, or toward, the mesial plane; mesiad

mesityl.definition: A hypothetical radical formerly supposed to exist in mesityl oxide

mesitylene.definition: A colorless, fragrant liquid, C6H3(CH3)3, of the benzene series of hydrocarbons, obtained by distilling acetone with sulphuric acid

mesitylol.definition: A crystalline substance obtained from mesitylene

mesmeree.definition: A person subjected to mesmeric influence; one who is mesmerized

mesmeric.definition: Of, pertaining to, or induced by, mesmerism; as, mesmeric sleep

mesmerism.definition: An earlier name for hypnosis or hypnotism, the art of inducing an extraordinary or abnormal state of the nervous system, in which the actor claims to control the actions, and communicate directly with the mind, of the recipient.  It is believed to be a state between sleep and wakefulness, in which a person is more susceptible to suggestion than when awake.  See Animal magnetism, under Magnetism

mesmerist.definition: One who practices, or believes in, mesmerism

mesmerization.definition: The act of mesmerizing; the state of being mesmerized

mesmerize.definition: To bring into a state of mesmeric sleep; to hypnotize
To produce an intense fascination in; to spellbind

mesne.definition: Middle; intervening; as, a mesne lord, that is, a lord who holds land of a superior, but grants a part of it to another person, in which case he is a tenant to the superior, but lord or superior to the second grantee, and hence is called the mesne lord

meso-.definition: A combining form denoting in the middle, intermediate
Denoting a type of hydrocarbons which are regarded as methenyl derivatives. Also used adjectively
Optically inactive due to compensating optical activity at two or more asymmetric centers, often due to a plane of symmetry within the molecular structure; as, meso-tartaric acid
Attached to a carbon atom located between two hereoatoms in a heterocyclic ring

mesoarium.definition: The fold of peritoneum which suspends the ovary from the dorsal wall of the body cavity; the mesovarium

mesoblastic.definition: Relating to the mesoblast; as, the mesoblastic layer

mesobranchial.definition: Of or pertaining to a region of the carapace of a crab covering the middle branchial region

mesobronchium.definition: The main bronchus of each lung

mesocaecum.definition: The fold of peritoneum attached to the caecum

mesocarp.definition: The middle layer of a pericarp which consists of three distinct or dissimilar layers

mesocephalic.definition: Of or pertaining to, or in the region of, the middle of the head; as, the mesocephalic flexure

mesocoele.definition: The cavity of the mesencephalon; the iter

mesocolon.definition: The fold of peritoneum, or mesentery, attached to the colon

mesocoracoid.definition: A process from the middle of the coracoid in some animals

mesocuneiform.definition: One of the bones of the tarsus. See 2d Cuneiform

mesoderm.definition: The layer of the blastoderm, between the ectoderm and endoderm; mesoblast. See Illust. of Blastoderm and Ectoderm

mesodermal.definition: Pertaining to, or derived from, the mesoderm; as, mesodermal tissues

mesogaster.definition: The fold of peritoneum connecting the stomach with the dorsal wall of the abdominal cavity; the mesogastrium

mesogastric.definition: Of or pertaining to the middle region of the abdomen, or of the stomach
Of or pertaining to the middle gastric lobe of the carapace of a crab

mesogloea.definition: A thin gelatinous tissue separating the ectoderm and endoderm in certain coelenterates

mesognathous.definition: Having the jaws slightly projecting; between prognathous and orthognathous. See Gnathic index, under Gnathic

mesohepar.definition: A fold of the peritoneum connecting the liver with the dorsal wall of the abdominal cavity
