milfoil.definition: A common composite herb (Achillea Millefolium) with white flowers and finely dissected leaves; yarrow

miliaria.definition: A fever accompanied by an eruption of small, isolated, red pimples, resembling a millet seed in form or size; miliary fever

miliary.definition: Like millet seeds; as, a miliary eruption
Accompanied with an eruption like millet seeds; as, a miliary fever
Small and numerous; as, the miliary tubercles of Echini
One of the small tubercles of Echini

miliola.definition: A genus of Foraminifera, having a porcelanous shell with several longitudinal chambers

miliolite.definition: A fossil shell of, or similar to, the genus Miliola

miliolitic.definition: Of or pertaining to the genus Miliola; containing miliolites

militancy.definition: The state of being militant; warfare
A military spirit or system; militarism

militant.definition: Engaged in warfare; fighting; combating; serving as a soldier

militarism.definition: A military state or condition; a military system; reliance on military force in administering government
The spirit and traditions of military life
The view that military strength, efficiency and values should dominate the country's public policy choices and take precedence over other interests
The policy of maintaining a large military force, even in peacetime; -- a term usually used by opponents of such a policy on the assumption that such a large force is unnecessary for national defense

militarist.definition: A person having a strong spirit of militarism, in senses 3 or 4

militaristic.definition: imbued with militarism, in senses 3 or 4

militarization.definition: act of assembling and putting into readiness the military forces for war or other emergency

militarize.definition: to lend a military character to (a country), as by building up a military force

militarized.definition: Equipped with weapons; armed; -- used of persons, regions, or the military.  Contrasted to unarmed and demilitarized; as, if that's a demilitarized zone, I wonder what a militarized zone would look like

military.definition: Of or pertaining to soldiers, to arms, or to war; belonging to, engaged in, or appropriate to, the affairs of war; as, a military parade; military discipline; military bravery; military conduct; military renown
Performed or made by soldiers; as, a military election; a military expedition
The whole body of soldiers; soldiery; militia; troops; the army

militate.definition: To make war; to fight; to contend; -- usually followed by against and with

militate against.definition: To argue against; to cast doubt on; -- used in reference to facts which tend to disprove a hypothesis; as, the absence of a correlation of budget deficits with inflation militates against any causal relation between the two.  Opposite of support

militia.definition: In the widest sense, the whole military force of a nation, including both those engaged in military service as a business, and those competent and available for such service; specifically, the body of citizens enrolled for military instruction and discipline, but not subject to be called into actual service except in emergencies

militiaman.definition: One who belongs to the militia

militiate.definition: To carry on, or prepare for, war

milk.definition: A white fluid secreted by the mammary glands of female mammals for the nourishment of their young, consisting of minute globules of fat suspended in a solution of casein, albumin, milk sugar, and inorganic salts
A kind of juice or sap, usually white in color, found in certain plants; latex. See Latex
An emulsion made by bruising seeds; as, the milk of almonds, produced by pounding almonds with sugar and water
The ripe, undischarged spat of an oyster
To draw or press milk from the breasts or udder of, by the hand or mouth; to withdraw the milk of
To draw from the breasts or udder; to extract, as milk; as, to milk wholesome milk from healthy cows
To draw anything from, as if by milking; to compel to yield profit or advantage; to plunder
To draw or to yield milk
To give off small gas bubbles during the final part of the charging operation; -- said of a storage battery

milk sickness.definition: A peculiar malignant disease, occurring in parts of the western United States, and affecting certain kinds of farm stock (esp. cows), and persons using the meat or dairy products of infected cattle. Its chief symptoms in man are uncontrollable vomiting, obstinate constipation, pain, and muscular tremors. Its origin in cattle has been variously ascribed to the presence of certain plants in their food, and to polluted water

milk vetch.definition: A leguminous herb (Astragalus glycyphyllos) of Europe and Asia, supposed to increase the secretion of milk in goats

milkcap.definition: A type of edible mushroom (Lactarius delicioso)

milker.definition: One who milks; also, a mechanical apparatus for milking cows
A cow or other animal that gives milk

milkful.definition: Full of milk; abounding with food

milkiness.definition: State or quality of being milky

milkmaid.definition: A woman who milks cows or is employed in the dairy

milkman.definition: A man who sells milk or delivers it to customers

milkshake.definition: A frothy drink of milk and flavoring and sometimes fruit or ice cream, shaken together or blended in  a blender

milksop.definition: A piece of bread sopped in milk; figuratively, an effeminate or weak-minded person

milkweed.definition: Any plant of the genera Asclepias and Acerates, abounding in a milky juice, and having its seed attached to a long silky down; silkweed.  The name is also applied to several other plants with a milky juice, as to several kinds of spurge.  Its leaves are a favorite food source for the larvae of the monarch butterfly

milkwort.definition: A genus of plants (Polygala) of many species.  The common European Polygala vulgaris was supposed to have the power of producing a flow of milk in nurses

milky.definition: Like, or somewhat like, milk; whitish and turbid; as, the water is milky. “Milky juice.”

mill.definition: A money of account of the United States, having the value of the tenth of a cent, or the thousandth of a dollar
A machine for grinding or comminuting any substance, as grain, by rubbing and crushing it between two hard, rough, or indented surfaces; as, a gristmill, a coffee mill; a bone mill
A machine used for expelling the juice, sap, etc., from vegetable tissues by pressure, or by pressure in combination with a grinding, or cutting process; as, a cider mill; a cane mill
A machine for grinding and polishing; as, a lapidary mill
A common name for various machines which produce a manufactured product, or change the form of a raw material by the continuous repetition of some simple action; as, a sawmill; a stamping mill, etc
A building or collection of buildings with machinery by which the processes of manufacturing are carried on; as, a cotton mill; a powder mill; a rolling mill
A hardened steel roller having a design in relief, used for imprinting a reversed copy of the design in a softer metal, as copper
An excavation in rock, transverse to the workings, from which material for filling is obtained
A milling cutter. See Illust. under Milling
A pugilistic encounter
Short for Treadmill
The raised or ridged edge or surface made in milling anything, as a coin or screw
A building or complex of buildings containing a mill{1} or other machinery to grind grains into flour
To reduce to fine particles, or to small pieces, in a mill; to grind; to comminute
To shape, finish, or transform by passing through a machine; specifically, to shape or dress, as metal, by means of a rotary cutter
To make a raised border around the edges of, or to cut fine grooves or indentations across the edges of, as of a coin, or a screw head; also, to stamp in a coining press; to coin
To pass through a fulling mill; to full, as cloth
To beat with the fists
To roll into bars, as steel
To swim under water; -- said of air-breathing creatures
To undergo hulling, as maize
To move in a circle, as cattle upon a plain; to move around aimlessly; -- usually used with around
To swim suddenly in a new direction; -- said of whales
To take part in a mill; to box
To fill (a winze or interior incline) with broken ore, to be drawn out at the bottom
To cause to mill, or circle round, as cattle

mill-cake.definition: The incorporated materials for gunpowder, in the form of a dense mass or cake, ready to be subjected to the process of granulation

mill-girl.definition: a girl who works in a mill

mill-sixpence.definition: A milled sixpence; -- the sixpence being one of the first English coins milled (1561)

milldam.definition: A dam or mound to obstruct a water course, and raise the water to a height sufficient to turn a mill wheel

milled.definition: Having been subjected to some process of milling

Having multiple fine grooves on the rim, in the direction from obverse to reverse; -- of coins.  Coins of silver and gold were milled to make it impossible for uncrupulous persons to shave small pieces from the edge without detection

millefiore glass.definition: Slender rods or tubes of colored glass fused together and embedded in clear glass; -- used for paperweights and other small articles

millenarian.definition: Consisting of a thousand years; of or pertaining to the millennium, or to the Millenarians
One who believes that Christ will personally reign on earth a thousand years; a Chiliast

millenary.definition: The space of a thousand years; a millennium; also, a Millenarian

millennial.definition: Of or pertaining to the millennium, or to a thousand years; as, a millennial period; millennial happiness

millennialist.definition: One who believes that Christ will reign personally on earth a thousand years; a Chiliast; also, a believer in the universal prevalence of Christianity for a long period

millennianism.definition: Belief in, or expectation of, the millennium{2}; millenarianism

millennist.definition: One who believes in the millennium{2}

millennium.definition: A period of one thousand years

The period of a thousand years mentioned in the twentieth chapter of Revelation, during which holiness is to be triumphant throughout the world.  Some believe that, during this period, Christ will reign on earth in person with his saints
A long period of happiness, righteousness, and prosperity, usually considered as being in the indefinite future

millennium bug.definition: An error in the coding of certain computer programs which store the year component of the date as two digits, assuming that the first two digits are 19, rather than as a complete number of four digits; when such programs are used after January 1, 2000, the date may be misinterpreted, causing serious errors or total failure of the program; -- called also year 2000 bug, year 2000 problem and Y2K bug

milleped.definition: A myriapod with many legs, esp. a chilognath, as the galleyworm

millepora.definition: A genus of Hydrocorallia, which includes the millipores

millepore.definition: Any coral of the genus Millepora, having the surface nearly smooth, and perforated with very minute unequal pores, or cells. The animals are hydroids, not Anthozoa. See Hydrocorallia

miller.definition: One who keeps or attends a flour mill or gristmill
A moth or lepidopterous insect; -- so called because the wings appear as if covered with white dust or powder, like a miller's clothes. Called also moth miller

millerite.definition: A believer in the doctrine of William Miller (d. 1849), who taught that the end of the world and the second coming of Christ were at hand
A sulphide of nickel, commonly occurring in delicate capillary crystals, also in incrustations of a bronze yellow; -- sometimes called hair pyrites

millesimal.definition: Thousandth; consisting of thousandth parts; as, millesimal fractions

millet.definition: The name of several cereal and forage grasses which bear an abundance of small roundish grains. The common millets of Germany and Southern Europe are Panicum miliaceum, and Setaria Italica

milli-.definition: A prefix denoting a thousandth part of; as, millimeter, milligram, milliampère

milliammeter.definition: a sensitive ammeter for detecting small currents, graduated in milliamperes

milliampere.definition: The thousandth part of one ampere

milliard.definition: A thousand millions; -- usually called billion in the United States.   See Billion

milliary.definition: Of or pertaining to a mile, or to distance by miles; denoting a mile or miles

millier.definition: A weight of the metric system, being one million grams; a metric ton

milligram.definition: A measure of mass and weight, in the metric system, being the thousandth part of a gram, very nearly equal to the weight of a cubic millimeter of water, or .01543 of a grain avoirdupois

milliliter.definition: A measure of capacity in the metric system, containing the thousandth part of a liter.  It is very nearly equal to a cubic centimeter, and is equal to .061025 of an English cubic inch, or to .033815 of an American fluid ounce

millimeter.definition: A lineal measure in the metric system, containing the thousandth part of a meter; equal to .03937 of an inch. See 3d Meter

millimicron.definition: The thousandth part of a micron or the millionth part of a millimeter; one nanometer; -- a unit of length sometimes used in measuring light waves, etc

milline.definition: an advertising measure; one agate line appearing in one million copies of a publication

milliner.definition: Formerly, a man who imported and dealt in small articles of a miscellaneous kind, especially such as please the fancy of women
A person who designs, makes, trims, or deals in hats, bonnets, headdresses, etc., for women

millinery.definition: The articles made or sold by milliners, as headdresses, hats or bonnets, laces, ribbons, and the like
The business of work of a milliner

millinet.definition: A stiff cotton fabric used by milliners for lining bonnets

milling.definition: The act or employment of grinding or passing through a mill; the process of fulling; the process of making a raised or intented edge upon coin, etc.; the process of dressing surfaces of various shapes with rotary cutters. See Mill

million.definition: The number of ten hundred thousand, or a thousand thousand, -- written 1,000,000. See the Note under Hundred
A very great number; an indefinitely large number
The mass of common people; -- with the article the

millionaire.definition: One whose wealth is counted by millions of francs, dollars, or pounds; a very rich person; a person worth a million or more

millionairess.definition: A woman who is a millionaire, or the wife of a millionaire

millionary.definition: Of or pertaining to millions; consisting of millions; as, the millionary chronology of the pundits

millionth.definition: Being the last one of a million of units or objects counted in regular order from the first of a series or succession; being one of a million
The quotient of a unit divided by one million; one of a million equal parts

milliweber.definition: The thousandth part of one weber

millpond.definition: a pond formed by damming a stream to provide a head of water to turn a mill wheel

millrace.definition: a channel from a millpond to a millwheel, to provide the water current that turns the millwheel

millrind.definition: A figure supposed to represent the iron which holds a millstone by being set into its center

millstone.definition: One of two circular stones used for grinding grain or other substance in a mill{1}

millwheel.definition: a waterwheel that is used to drive machinery in a mill

millwork.definition: The shafting, gearing, and other driving machinery of mills
The business of setting up or of operating mill machinery

millwright.definition: A mechanic whose occupation is to build mills, or to set up their machinery

milometer.definition: a meter that shows mileage traversed

milord.definition: Lit., my lord; hence (as used on the Continent), an English nobleman or gentleman

milquetoast.definition: a timid, unassertive man or boy fearful of confrontation and easily manipulated and dominated

milreis.definition: A Portuguese money of account rated in the treasury department of the United States at one dollar and eight cents; also, a Brazilian money of account rated at fifty-four cents and six mills (1913)

milt.definition: To impregnate (the roe of a fish) with milt

miltonic.definition: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, Milton, or his writings; as, Miltonic prose

miltwaste.definition: A small European fern (Asplenium Ceterach) formerly used in medicine

milvine.definition: Of or resembling birds of the kite kind
A bird related to the kite

milvus.definition: A genus of raptorial birds, including the European kite

mime.definition: A kind of drama in which real persons and events were generally represented in a ridiculous manner; an ancient Greek or Roman form of farce
The art of representing actions, events, situations, or stories solely by gestures and body movements, without speaking; pantomime{3}
An actor who performs or specializes in mime{3}; an actor who communicates entirely by gesture and facial expression; a pantomime{2}; a pantomimist; a mimer

mimeo.definition: to make copies of using a mimeograph

mimeograph.definition: A copying device that uses a stencil through which ink is pressed; it was invented by Edison
to make copies of using a mimeograph; as, She mimeographed the syllabus

mimer.definition: A person who performs in a mime

mimetic.definition: Apt to imitate; given to mimicry; imitative
Characterized by mimicry; -- applied to animals and plants; as, mimetic species; mimetic organisms. See Mimicry

mimetite.definition: A mineral occurring in pale yellow or brownish hexagonal crystals. It is an arseniate of lead

mimic.definition: Consisting of, or formed by, imitation; imitated; as, mimic gestures
Imitative; characterized by resemblance to other forms; -- applied to crystals which by twinning resemble simple forms of a higher grade of symmetry
One who imitates or mimics, especially one who does so for sport; a copyist; a buffoon
To imitate or ape for sport; to ridicule by imitation
To assume a resemblance to (some other organism of a totally different nature, or some surrounding object), as a means of protection or advantage

mimicker.definition: An animal which imitates something else, in form or habits

mimicry.definition: The act or practice of one who mimics; ludicrous imitation for sport or ridicule

Protective resemblance; the resemblance which certain animals and plants exhibit to other animals and plants or to the natural objects among which they live, -- a characteristic which serves as their chief means of protection against enemies; imitation; mimesis; mimetism

mimir.definition: A giant who guarded the well of wisdom

mimosa.definition: A genus of leguminous plants, containing many species, and including the sensitive plants (Mimosa sensitiva, and Mimosa pudica)

mimosaceae.definition: A natural family of spiny woody plants (usually shrubs or small trees) whose leaves mimic animals in sensitivity to touch; commonly included in the family Leguminosae

mimosoideae.definition: An alternative name used in some classification systems for the family Mimosaceae

mimotannic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, a variety of tannin or tannic acid found in Acacia, Mimosa, etc

mimus.definition: The type genus of the family Mimidae, comprising certain of the mockingbirds

synonyms: Syn. -- Min dialect, Fukkianese, Hokkianese, Amoy, Taiwanese.

min..definition: An abbreviation for minute, a unit of time equal to 60 seconds or 1/60th of an hour

mina.definition: An ancient weight or denomination of money, of varying value.  The Attic mina was valued at a hundred drachmas

minable.definition: Such as can be mined; as, minable earth

minaceous.definition: Of the color of minium or red lead; miniate

minaret.definition: A slender, lofty tower attached to a mosque and surrounded by one or more projecting balconies, from which the summon to prayer is cried by the muezzin

minargent.definition: An alloy consisting of copper, nickel, tungsten, and aluminium; -- used by jewelers

minatorially.definition: In a minatory manner; with threats

mince.definition: To cut into very small pieces; to chop fine; to hash; as, to mince meat

To suppress or weaken the force of; to extenuate; to palliate; to tell by degrees, instead of directly and frankly; to clip, as words or expressions; to utter half and keep back half of; as, he doesn't mince words
To affect; to make a parade of
To walk with short steps; to walk in a prim, affected manner
To act or talk with affected nicety; to affect delicacy in manner
A short, precise step; an affected manner

mince-meat.definition: Minced meat; meat chopped very fine; a mixture of boiled meat, suet, apples, etc., chopped very fine, to which spices and raisins are added; -- used in making mince pie

mincing.definition: That minces; characterized by primness or affected nicety

mincingly.definition: In a mincing manner; not fully; with affected nicety

mind.definition: The intellectual or rational faculty in man; the understanding; the intellect; the power that conceives, judges, or reasons; also, the entire spiritual nature; the soul; -- often in distinction from the body
The state, at any given time, of the faculties of thinking, willing, choosing, and the like; psychical activity or state
Memory; remembrance; recollection; as, to have or keep in mind, to call to mind, to put in mind, etc
To fix the mind or thoughts on; to regard with attention; to treat as of consequence; to consider; to heed; to mark; to note
To occupy one's self with; to employ one's self about; to attend to; as, to mind one's business
To obey; as, to mind parents; the dog minds his master
To have in mind; to purpose
To put in mind; to remind
To give attention or heed; to obey; as, the dog minds well

mind-altering.definition: producing mood changes or distorted perception; -- used mostly of psychoactive substances; as, hallucinogenic drugs are mind-altering substances

mind-bending.definition: intensely affecting the mind, especially in producing hallucinations; -- usually of chemical substances

mind-blowing.definition: intensely affecting the mind or emotions; astonishing; -- usually referring to extraordinary experiences; as, spending a week in the jungle was a mind-blowing experience; a mind-blowing horror story

mind-boggling.definition: intellectually or emotionally overwhelming; straining one's capacity to comprehend or cope; as, a mind-boggling display; a mind-boggling puzzle

minden.definition: A battle in the Seven Years' War (1759) in which the Anglo-Allied forces under duke Ferdinand of Brunswick defeated the French under Marshal Contades

minder.definition: One who minds, tends, or watches something, as a child, a machine, or cattle; as, a minder of a loom
One to be attended; specif., a pauper child intrusted to the care of a private person

mindful.definition: Bearing in mind; regardful; attentive; heedful; observant

mindless.definition: Not indued with mind or intellectual powers; stupid; unthinking

mine.definition: Belonging to me; my. Used as a pronominal to me; my. Used as a pronominal adjective in the predicate; as, “Vengeance is mine; I will repay.” Rom. xii. 19. Also, in the old style, used attributively, instead of my, before a noun beginning with a vowel

To dig a mine or pit in the earth; to get ore, metals, coal, or precious stones, out of the earth; to dig in the earth for minerals; to dig a passage or cavity under anything in order to overthrow it by explosives or otherwise
To form subterraneous tunnel or hole; to form a burrow or lodge in the earth; as, the mining cony
To dig away, or otherwise remove, the substratum or foundation of; to lay a mine under; to sap; to undermine; hence, to ruin or destroy by slow degrees or secret means
To dig into, for ore or metal
To get, as metals, out of the earth by digging
Any place where ore, metals, or precious stones are got by digging or washing the soil; as, a placer mine
A rich source of wealth or other good

An explosive device placed concealed in a location, on land or at sea, where an enemy vehicle or enemy personnel may pass through, having a triggering mechanism which detects people or vehicles, and which will explode and kill or maim personnel or destroy or damage vehicles.  A mine placed at sea (formerly called a torpedo, see torpedo{2} (a)) is also called an marine mine and underwater mine and sometimes called a floating mine, even though it may be anchored to the floor of the sea and not actually float freely.  A mine placed on land (formerly called a torpedo, see torpedo{3}), usually buried, is called a land mine

mined.definition: extracted from a source of supply as of minerals from the earth

minefield.definition: a region in which explosive mines{4} have been placed, especially a region on land

A situation in which a simple mistake can have disastrous consequences; a touchy or dangerous situation requiring great caution; as, the candidate threaded his way skillfully through a minefield of loaded questions from the audience

minelayer.definition: a ship equipped for laying underwater mines

minelaying.definition: The act or process of laying explosive mines in concealed places to destroy enemy personnel and equipment

miner.definition: One who mines; a digger for metals, etc.; one engaged in the business of getting ore, coal, or precious stones, out of the earth; one who digs military mines; as, armies have sappers and miners
Any of numerous insects which, in the larval state, excavate galleries in the parenchyma of leaves.  They are mostly minute moths and dipterous flies

mineral.definition: An inorganic species or substance occurring in nature, having a definite chemical composition and usually a distinct crystalline form.  Rocks, except certain glassy igneous forms, are either simple minerals or aggregates of minerals
Anything which is neither animal nor vegetable, as in the most general classification of things into three kingdoms (animal, vegetable, and mineral)
Of or pertaining to minerals; consisting of a mineral or of minerals; as, a mineral substance
Impregnated with minerals; as, mineral waters

mineralization.definition: The process of mineralizing, or forming a mineral by combination of a metal with another element; also, the process of converting into a mineral, as a bone or a plant
The act of impregnating with a mineral, as water
The conversion of a cell wall into a material of a stony nature

mineralize.definition: To impregnate with a mineral; as, mineralized water
To charge or impregnate with ore
To go on an excursion for observing and collecting minerals; to mineralogize

mineralized.definition: containing or impregnated with minerals; as, mineralized water; red stains that signify mineralized land

mineralizer.definition: An element which is combined with a metal, thus forming an ore.  Thus, in galena, or lead ore, sulphur is a mineralizer; in hematite, oxygen is a mineralizer

mineralogical.definition: Of or pertaining to mineralogy; as, a mineralogical table

mineralogically.definition: According to the principles of, or with reference to, mineralogy

mineralogist.definition: One versed in mineralogy; one devoted to the study of minerals

mineralogize.definition: To study mineralogy by collecting and examining minerals

mineralogy.definition: The science which treats of minerals, and teaches how to describe, distinguish, and classify them
A treatise or book on this science

minerva.definition: The goddess of wisdom, of war, of the arts and sciences, of poetry, and of spinning and weaving; -- identified with the Grecian Pallas Athene

minesweeper.definition: A boat designed for the purpose of detecting and disposing of marine mines

minesweeping.definition: the activity of detecting and disposing of marine mines

minette.definition: The smallest of regular sizes of portrait photographs

minge.definition: A small biting fly; a midge

synonyms: Syn. -- meanness, niggardliness, niggardness, parsimony, parsimoniousness, tightfistedness.

mingle.definition: To mix; intermix; to combine or join, as an individual or part, with other parts, but commonly so as to be distinguishable in the product; to confuse; to confound
To associate or unite in society or by ties of relationship; to cause or allow to intermarry; to intermarry
To deprive of purity by mixture; to contaminate
To make or prepare by mixing the ingredients of
To associate (with certain people); as, he's too highfalutin to mingle with working stiffs
To move (among other people); -- of people; as, the president left his car to mingle with the crowd; a host at a a party should mingle with his guests

mingle-mangle.definition: To mix in a disorderly way; to make a mess of

minglement.definition: The act of mingling, or the state of being mixed

miniate.definition: To paint or tinge with red lead or vermilion; also, to decorate with letters, or the like, painted red, as the page of a manuscript
Of or pertaining to the color of red lead or vermilion; painted with vermilion

miniature.definition: Originally, a painting in colors such as those in mediaeval manuscripts; in modern times, any very small painting, especially a portrait
Greatly diminished size or form; reduced scale
Being on a small scale; much reduced from the reality; as, a miniature copy
To represent or depict in a small compass, or on a small scale

miniaturization.definition: The act or process of making on a greatly reduced scale

miniaturize.definition: To design or construct on a smaller scale

minibus.definition: A kind of light passenger vehicle, carrying four persons

A type of bus (omnibus) similar in general appearnace to a standard-sized bus, but smaller and having a smaller passenger capacity, typically about 15 persons.  It is usually used for transportation over relatively short distances

minicomputer.definition: a mid-sized digital computer; at any given point in the development of computer technology, a minicomputer will be faster and have greater capacity than a microcomputer, but will be slower and have less capacity than a mainframe computer

minie ball.definition: A conical rifle bullet, with a cavity in its base plugged with a piece of iron, which, by the explosion of the charge, is driven farther in, expanding the sides to fit closely the grooves of the barrel

minie rifle.definition: A rifle adapted to minie balls

minify.definition: To make small, or smaller; to diminish the apparent dimensions of; to lessen
To degrade by speech or action

minikin.definition: A little darling; a favorite; a minion

minim.definition: Anything very minute; as, the minims of existence; -- applied to animalcula; and the like

The smallest liquid measure, equal to about one drop; the sixtieth part of a fluid drachm, equal to one four-hundred-eightieth of a fluid ounce, or 0.06161 milliliter (U. S. measure) or 0.05919 milliliters (British measure)
A little man or being; a dwarf
One of an austere order of mendicant hermits or friars founded in the 15th century by St. Francis of Paola
A time note, formerly the shortest in use; a half note, equal to half a semibreve, or two quarter notes or crotchets

minimal.definition: Of, pertaining to, or having a character of, a minim or minimum; least; smallest; as, a minimal amount or value

miniment.definition: A trifle; a trinket; a token

minimization.definition: The act or process of minimizing

minimize.definition: To reduce to the smallest part or proportion possible; to reduce to a minimum
To represent, to oneself or others, as of no importance or minimal importance or effect; to belittle or disarage

minimized.definition: Reduced to the smallest possible size or amount or degree

minimum.definition: The least quantity assignable, admissible, or possible, in a given case; hence, a thing of small consequence; -- opposed to maximum

minimus.definition: A being of the smallest size
The little finger; the fifth digit, or that corresponding to it, in either the manus or pes

mining.definition: The act or business of making mines or of working them
Of or pertaining to mines; as, mining engineer; mining machinery; a mining region

minion.definition: A loved one; one highly esteemed and favored; -- in a good sense
An obsequious or servile dependent or agent of another; a fawning favorite
A small kind of type, in size between brevier and nonpareil
An ancient form of ordnance, the caliber of which was about three inches

minionette.definition: A size of type between nonpareil and minion; -- used in ornamental borders, etc

minious.definition: Of the color of red or vermilion

minishment.definition: The act of diminishing, or the state of being diminished; diminution

minister.definition: A servant; a subordinate; an officer or assistant of inferior rank; hence, an agent, an instrument
One to whom the sovereign or executive head of a government intrusts the management of affairs of state, or some department of such affairs
A representative of a government, sent to the court, or seat of government, of a foreign nation to transact diplomatic business
One who serves at the altar; one who performs sacerdotal duties; the pastor of a church duly authorized or licensed to preach the gospel and administer the sacraments
To furnish or apply; to afford; to supply; to administer
To act as a servant, attendant, or agent; to attend and serve; to perform service in any office, sacred or secular
To supply or to things needful; esp., to supply consolation or remedies; as, to minister to the sick

ministerial.definition: Of or pertaining to ministry or service; serving; attendant
Of or pertaining to the office of a minister or to the ministry as a body, whether civil or sacerdotal
Tending to advance or promote; contributive

ministerialist.definition: A supporter of the ministers, or the party in power

ministerially.definition: In a ministerial manner; in the character or capacity of a minister

ministrant.definition: Performing service as a minister; attendant on service; acting under command; subordinate

ministration.definition: The act of ministering; service; ministry

ministry.definition: The act of ministering; ministration; service
The office, duties, or functions of a minister, servant, or agent; ecclesiastical, executive, or ambassadorial function or profession
The body of ministers of state; also, the clergy, as a body
Administration; rule; term in power; as, the ministry of Pitt

minium.definition: A heavy, brilliant red pigment, consisting of an oxide of lead, Pb3O4, obtained by exposing lead or massicot to a gentle and continued heat in the air.  It is used as a cement, as a paint, and in the manufacture of flint glass.  Called also red lead, lead tetroxide, lead orthoplumbate, mineral orange, mineral red, Paris red, Saturn red, and less definitively, lead oxide

miniver.definition: A fur esteemed in the Middle Ages as a part of costume.  It is uncertain whether it was the fur of one animal only or of different animals

minivet.definition: A singing bird of India of the family Campephagidae

mink.definition: A carnivorous mammal of the genus Mustela (foremrly Putorius), allied to the weasel.  The European mink is Mustela lutreola.  The common American mink (Mustela vison) varies from yellowish brown to black.  Its fur is highly valued.  Called also minx, nurik, and vison
The fur of the mink{1}.    Together with sable, it is one of the most expensive furs not taken from endangerd species.  When the fur is taken from animals grown on a farm, it called ranch mink

minnesinger.definition: A love-singer; specifically, one of a class of German poets and musicians who flourished from about the middle of the twelfth to the middle of the fourteenth century.  They were chiefly of noble birth, and made love and beauty the subjects of their verses

minniebush.definition: A low shrub (Menziesia pilosa) of the eastern U. S. with downy twigs

minnow.definition: A small European fresh-water cyprinoid fish (Phoxinus laevis, formerly Leuciscus phoxinus); sometimes applied also to the young of larger kinds; -- called also minim and minny. The name is also applied to several allied American species, of the genera Phoxinus, Notropis, or Minnilus, and Rhinichthys
Any of numerous small American cyprinodont fishes of the genus Fundulus, and related genera. They live both in fresh and in salt water. Called also killifish, minny, and mummichog

mino bird.definition: An Asiatic bird (Gracula musica), allied to the starlings.  It is black, with a white spot on the wings, and a pair of flat yellow wattles on the head.  It is often tamed and taught to pronounce words.  It is one of the birds called mynah bird

minor.definition: Inferior in bulk, degree, importance, etc.; less; smaller; of little account; as, minor divisions of a body
Less by a semitone in interval or difference of pitch; as, a minor third
A person of either sex who has not attained the age at which full civil rights are accorded; an infant; in England and the United States, one under twenty-one years of age

The minor term, that is, the subject of the conclusion; also, the minor premise, that is, that premise which contains the minor term; in hypothetical syllogisms, the categorical premise.  It is the second proposition of a regular syllogism, as in the following: Every act of injustice partakes of meanness; to take money from another by gaming is an act of injustice; therefore, the taking of money from another by gaming partakes of meanness

minor league.definition: A league of professional sports teams less proficient than a major leagues.  Players in the minor leagues generally are paid less than those in the major leagues, and their games attract less atention

minor-league.definition: Of or pertaining to a minor league
Of mediocre talent or poor accomplishment; unimportant; -- of people; as, a minor-league physicist

minorat.definition: A custom or right, analogous to borough-English in England, formerly existing in various parts of Europe, and surviving in parts of Germany and Austria, by which certain entailed estates, as a homestead and adjacent land, descend to the youngest male heir

minority.definition: The state of being a minor, or under age
State of being less or small
The smaller number; -- opposed to majority; as, the minority must be ruled by the majority
Those members of a legislature that belong to the political party which is in the minority in that institution; as, the bill will pass even if the minority are strongly opposed

minors.definition: The minor leagues, those leagues of professional sports teams less proficient than the majors, or major leagues

minos.definition: A king and lawgiver of Crete, fabled to be the son of Jupiter and Europa.  After death he was made a judge in the Lower Regions

minotaur.definition: A fabled monster, half man and half bull, confined in the labyrinth constructed by Daedalus in Crete

minster.definition: A church of a monastery.  The name is often retained and applied to the church after the monastery has ceased to exist (as Beverly Minster, Southwell Minster, etc.), and is also improperly used for any large church

minstrel.definition: In the Middle Ages, one of an order of men who subsisted by the arts of poetry and music, and sang verses to the accompaniment of a harp or other instrument; in modern times, a poet; a bard; a singer and harper; a musician

minstrelsy.definition: The arts and occupation of minstrels; the singing and playing of a minstrel
A collective body of minstrels, or musicians; also, a collective body of minstrels' songs

mint.definition: The name of several aromatic labiate plants, mostly of the genus Mentha, yielding odoriferous essential oils by distillation. See Mentha
A place where money is coined by public authority
Any place regarded as a source of unlimited supply; the supply itself
A large quantity of money; as, to make a mint in stock trading
To make by stamping, as money; to coin; to make and stamp into money
To invent; to forge; to fabricate; to fashion
Like new; in brand-new condition; unworn, as a coin recently made at a mint{1}; as, he had a '53 Cadillac in mint condition
Uncirculated; in the same condition as when it was freshly coined at the mint{1}

mint sauce.definition: A sauce of vinegar and sugar flavored with spearmint leaves

mint state.definition: A numerical grade indicating the degree of perfection of the condition of a coin which is classified as uncirculated, ranging from 70 for a coin in perfect condition to 60 for a coin which is uncirculated but may have a weak strike, or numerous small scratches from being handled in mint bags; usually used as the abbreviation MS; as, an MS-67 Morgan Dollar

mint-master.definition: The master or superintendent of a mint. Also used figuratively

mintage.definition: The coin, or other production, made in a mint

The duty paid to the mint for coining.  At one time people could bring precious metals, as gold or silver, to a mint and receive in return coins of the same value, minus the commision charged by the mint, which was the mintage
The act or process of minting{1}; as, a coin of recent mintage
The quantity of coins of a specific type made by the mint; as, coins of low mintage tend to be more valuable as collectors' items

mintman.definition: One skilled in coining, or in coins; a coiner

minuend.definition: In the process of subtraction{2}, the number from which another number (the subtrahend) is to be subtracted, to find the difference

minuet.definition: A slow graceful dance consisting of a coupee, a high step, and a balance
A tune or air to regulate the movements of the dance so called; a movement in suites, sonatas, symphonies, etc., having the dance form, and commonly in 3-4, sometimes 3-8, measure

minum.definition: A small kind of printing type; minion

minus.definition: Less; requiring to be subtracted; negative; as, a minus quantity

A factor counted as a disadvantage; a loss or potential loss in a situation or plan; as, he added up all the pluses and minuses and decided not to do it; as, the lack of money is a big minus in an election campaign

minuscular.definition: of or relating to minuscule script, a small cursive script developed from uncial, and used in the 7th to 9th centuries

minuscule.definition: A small Roman letter which is neither capital nor uncial; a manuscript written in such letters
Of or relating to a minuscule{2} or of a script written in minuscules{2}; of the size and style of minuscules{2}; written in minuscules{2}; minuscular

minutary.definition: Pertaining to, or consisting of, minutes

minute.definition: The sixtieth part of an hour; sixty seconds. (Abbrev. m. or min.; as, 4 h. 30 m.)
The sixtieth part of a degree; sixty seconds (Marked thus (′); as, 10° 20′)
A nautical or a geographic mile
A very small part of anything, or anything very small; a jot; a tittle
A point of time; a moment
The memorandum; a record; a note to preserve the memory of anything; as, to take minutes of a contract; to take minutes of a conversation or debate; to read the minutes of the last meeting
A fixed part of a module. See Module
Of or pertaining to a minute or minutes; occurring at or marking successive minutes
To set down a short sketch or note of; to jot down; to make a minute or a brief summary of
Very small; little; tiny; fine; slight; slender; inconsiderable; as, minute details
Attentive to small things; paying attention to details; critical; particular; precise; as, a minute observer; minute observation

minute-jack.definition: A figure which strikes the hour on the bell of some fanciful clocks; -- called also jack of the clock house

minutely.definition: In a minute manner; with minuteness; exactly; nicely
At intervals of a minute; very often and regularly

minuteman.definition: A militiaman who was to be ready to march at a moment's notice; -- a term used in the American Revolution

minutia.definition: A minute particular; a small or minor detail; -- used chiefly in the plural

minx.definition: A pert or a wanton girl
A she puppy; a pet dog
The mink; -- called also minx otter

miny.definition: Abounding with mines; like a mine

minyan.definition: A quorum, or number necessary, for conducting public worship

miocene.definition: Of or pertaining to the middle division of the Tertiary

miohippus.definition: An extinct Miocene mammal of the Horse family, closely related to the genus Anhithecrium, and having three usable hoofs on each foot

miquelet.definition: An irregular or partisan soldier; a bandit

mira.definition: A remarkable variable star in the constellation Cetus (ο Ceti)

mirabilary.definition: One who, or a work which, narrates wonderful things; one who writes of wonders

mirabile dictu.definition: Remarkably; strange to say; marvelous to relate

mirabilis.definition: A genus of plants. See Four-o'clock

miracle.definition: An event or effect contrary to the established constitution and course of things, or a deviation from the known laws of nature; a supernatural event, or one transcending the ordinary laws by which the universe is governed
A story or legend abounding in miracles

miraculize.definition: To cause to seem to be a miracle

miraculous.definition: Of the nature of a miracle; performed by supernatural power; effected by the direct agency of almighty power, and not by natural causes

mirage.definition: An optical effect, sometimes seen on the ocean, but more frequently in deserts, due to total reflection of light at the surface common to two strata of air differently heated.  The reflected image is seen, commonly in an inverted position, while the real object may or may not be in sight.  When the surface is horizontal, and below the eye, the appearance is that of a sheet of water in which the object is seen reflected; when the reflecting surface is above the eye, the image is seen projected against the sky.  The fata Morgana and looming are species of mirage

mire.definition: To cause or permit to stick fast in mire; to plunge or fix in mud; as, to mire a horse or wagon
To stick or entangle; to involve in difficulties; -- often used in the passive or predicate form; as, we got mired in bureaucratic red tape and it took years longer than planned
To soil with mud or foul matter

mirliton.definition: A kind of musical toy into which one sings, hums, or speaks, producing a coarse, reedy sound.  It is also called a kazoo

mirounga.definition: A genus comprising the elephant seals

mirror.definition: A looking-glass or a speculum; any glass or polished substance that forms images by the reflection of rays of light
That which gives a true representation, or in which a true image may be seen; hence, a pattern; an exemplar
To reflect, as in a mirror
To copy or duplicate; to mimic or imitate; as, the files at Project Gutenberg were mirrored on several other ftp sites around the world
To have a close resemblance to; as, his opinions often mirrored those of his wife

mirrored.definition: Reflected in or as if in a mirror

mirrorlike.definition: capable of reflecting light like a mirror; flat and reflective; as, the mirrorlike surface of the lake

mirth.definition: Merriment; gayety accompanied with laughter; jollity

mirthful.definition: Full of mirth or merriment; merry; as, mirthful children
Indicating or inspiring mirth; as, a mirthful face

miry.definition: Abounding with deep mud; full of mire; muddy; as, a miry road

miryachit.definition: A nervous disease in which the patient involuntarily imitates the words or action of another

mirza.definition: The common title of honor in Persia, prefixed to the surname of an individual.  When appended to the surname, it signifies Prince

mis-.definition: A prefix used adjectively and adverbially in the sense of amiss, wrong, ill, wrongly, unsuitably; as, misdeed, mislead, mischief, miscreant

misacceptation.definition: Wrong acceptation; understanding in a wrong sense

misadjust.definition: To adjust wrongly of unsuitably; to throw out of adjustment

misadventure.definition: Mischance; misfortune; ill luck; unlucky accident; ill adventure

misaffection.definition: An evil or wrong affection; the state of being ill affected

misalignment.definition: The act of aligning improperly or state of being improperly aligned

misalliance.definition: A marriage with a person of inferior rank or social station; an improper alliance; a mesalliance

misalter.definition: To alter wrongly; esp., to alter for the worse

misandrist.definition: one who hates men.  Contrast misogynist and cf. misandry

misandry.definition: Hatred of men.  Contrast misogyny and cf. misandrist

misanthrope.definition: A hater of mankind; a misanthropist

misanthropy.definition: Hatred of, or dislike to, mankind; -- opposed to philanthropy

misapply.definition: To apply wrongly; to use for a wrong purpose; as, to misapply a name or title; to misapply public money

misapprehend.definition: To take in a wrong sense; to misunderstand

misapprehension.definition: A mistaking or mistake; wrong apprehension of one's meaning of a fact; misconception; misunderstanding

misappropriate.definition: To appropriate wrongly; to use for a wrong purpose

misappropriated.definition: taken for one's own use in violation of a trust

misarrange.definition: To place in a wrong order, or improper manner

misassay.definition: To assay, or attempt, improperly or unsuccessfully

misbear.definition: To carry improperly; to carry (one's self) wrongly; to misbehave

misbecome.definition: Not to become; to suit ill; not to befit or be adapted to

misbede.definition: To wrong; to do injury to

misbegot.definition: Unlawfully or irregularly begotten; of bad or disreputable origin; pernicious
Poorly designed or planned; badly carried out; ill-conceived

misbehave.definition: To behave ill; to conduct one's self improperly; -- often used with a reciprocal pronoun

misbehaved.definition: Guilty of ill behavior; illbred; rude

misbehavior.definition: Improper, rude, or uncivil behavior; ill conduct

misbelieve.definition: To believe erroneously, or in a false religion

misbeliever.definition: One who believes wrongly; one who holds a false religion

miscalculate.definition: To judge wrongly, especially about the effects of action or the likely course of events

miscalculation.definition: An error in judgment, especially about the effects of action or the likely course of events; as, IBM's miscalculation about the impact of microcomputers cost them many billions in lost opportunities; Sadam's invasion of Kuwait was only his worst, but not his last, miscalculation

miscall.definition: To call by a wrong name; to name improperly
To call by a bad name; to abuse

miscarriage.definition: Unfortunate event or issue of an undertaking; failure to attain a proper or desired result or reach a destination; as, a serious miscarriage of justice
Ill conduct; evil or improper behavior; as, the failings and miscarriages of the righteous
The act of bringing forth a child before the time it is viable; a premature birth, resulting in death of the fetus; spontaneous abortion

miscarriageable.definition: Capable of miscarrying; liable to fail

miscarry.definition: To carry, or go, wrong; to fail of reaching a destination, or fail of the intended effect; to be unsuccessful; to suffer defeat
To bring forth young before the time they are viable; to have a spontaneous abortion

miscegenate.definition: to marry or cohabit with a person of another race

miscegenation.definition: A mixing of races; amalgamation, as by intermarriage of black and white

miscellane.definition: A mixture of two or more sorts of grain; -- now called maslin and meslin

miscellanea.definition: A collection of miscellaneous matters; matters of various kinds

miscellaneous.definition: Mixed; mingled; consisting of several things; of diverse sorts; promiscuous; heterogeneous; as, a miscellaneous collection

miscellany.definition: A mass or mixture of various things; a medley; esp., a collection of compositions on various subjects

mischaracterize.definition: To characterize falsely or erroneously; to give a wrong character to

mischarge.definition: To charge erroneously, as in an account

mischief.definition: Harm; damage; esp., disarrangement of order; trouble or vexation caused by human agency or by some living being, intentionally or not; often, calamity, mishap; trivial evil caused by thoughtlessness, or in sport
Cause of trouble or vexation; trouble

mischief-maker.definition: One who makes mischief; one who excites or instigates quarrels or enmity

mischief-making.definition: Causing harm; exciting enmity or quarrels

mischievous.definition: Causing mischief; harmful; hurtful; -- now often applied where the evil is done carelessly or in sport; as, a mischievous child

miscible.definition: Mixable in all proportions; forming a single phase when mixed in any proportion; -- of liquids; as, water and alcohol are miscible in all proportions; water and gasoline are not miscible; benzene and ethyl alcohol are miscible, and ethyl alcohol is miscible with water, but water is not miscible with benzene

miscognize.definition: To fail to apprehend; to misunderstand

miscolor.definition: To give a wrong color to
To set forth erroneously or unfairly; to misrepresent; as, to miscolor facts

miscomprehend.definition: To get a wrong idea of or about; to misunderstand

misconceive.definition: To conceive wrongly; to interpret incorrectly; to receive a false notion of; to misunderstand; to misjudge; to misapprehend

misconception.definition: Erroneous conception; false opinion; wrong understanding

misconduct.definition: Unlawful or unethical conduct by a person holding a public office or having a position of responsibility in the administration of justice; malfeasance; as, discussing the case out of court during a trial is misconduct by a juror

misconfident.definition: Having a mistaken confidence; wrongly trusting

misconsequence.definition: A wrong consequence; a false deduction

misconstruable.definition: Such as can be misconstrued, as language or conduct

misconstruct.definition: To construct wrongly; to construe or interpret erroneously

misconstrue.definition: To construe wrongly; to interpret erroneously

miscontinuance.definition: Discontinuance; also, continuance by undue process

miscorrect.definition: To fail or err in attempting to correct

miscount.definition: An erroneous count of ballots cast in an election

miscreance.definition: The quality of being miscreant; adherence to a false religion; false faith

miscreant.definition: One who holds a false religious faith; a misbeliever
One not restrained by Christian principles; an unscrupulous villain; a depraved person; a vile wretch
Destitute of conscience; unscrupulous; villainous; base; depraved

miscreate.definition: Miscreated; illegitimate; forged; as, miscreate titles

miscredent.definition: A miscreant, or believer in a false religious doctrine

miscue.definition: A false stroke with a billiard cue, the cue slipping from the ball struck without impelling it as desired

misdate.definition: To put a false or erroneous date on (a document)
To assign an incorrect date to; as, the fall of Troy was misdated by medieval writers

misdating.definition: The assignment of a date to something at a time when it could not have existed or occurred

misdeal.definition: To deal or distribute wrongly, as cards; to make a wrong distribution
The act of misdealing; a wrong distribution of cards to the players

misdeed.definition: An evil deed; a wicked action

misdemean.definition: To behave ill; -- with a reflexive pronoun; as, to misdemean one's self

misdemeanor.definition: A crime less than a felony

misderive.definition: To turn or divert improperly; to misdirect

misdirect.definition: To give a wrong direction to; as, to misdirect a passenger, or a letter; to misdirect one's energies

misdirection.definition: The act of directing wrongly, or the state of being so directed
An error of a judge in charging the jury on a matter of law
The direction of another's attention to an unimportant place or matter, for the purpose of being able to perform an action undetected; as, misdirection is an important part of a magician's art

misdistinguish.definition: To make wrong distinctions in or concerning

misdo.definition: To do wrong to; to illtreat
To do wrong; to commit a fault

misdoing.definition: A wrong done; a fault or crime; an offense; as, it was my misdoing

misdoubt.definition: To be suspicious of; to have suspicion

mise.definition: The issue in a writ of right

A tax or tallage; in Wales, an honorary gift of the people to a new king or prince of Wales; also, a tribute paid, in the country palatine of Chester, England, at the change of the owner of the earldom

miseducate.definition: To educate in a wrong manner

misemploy.definition: To employ amiss; as, to misemploy time, advantages, talents, etc

misenter.definition: To enter or insert wrongly, as a charge in an account

misentry.definition: An erroneous entry or charge, as of an account

miser.definition: A wretched person; a person afflicted by any great misfortune
A covetous, grasping, mean person; esp., one having wealth, who lives miserably for the sake of saving and increasing his hoard
A stingy person; one very reluctant to spend money
A kind of large earth auger

miserable.definition: Very unhappy; wretched; living in misery
Worthless; mean; despicable; as, a miserable fellow; a miserable dinner

miserableness.definition: The state or quality of being miserable

miserably.definition: In a miserable; unhappily; calamitously; wretchedly; meanly

miserere.definition: The psalm usually appointed for penitential acts, being the 50th psalm in the Latin version.  It commences with the word miserere
A musical composition adapted to the 50th psalm

A small projecting boss or bracket, on the under side of the hinged seat of a church stall (see Stall).  It was intended, the seat being turned up, to give some support to a worshiper when standing.  Called also misericordia

misericordia.definition: A thin-bladed dagger; so called, in the Middle Ages, because used to give the death wound or “mercy” stroke to a fallen adversary
An indulgence as to food or dress granted to a member of a religious order

miserly.definition: Like a miser; very covetous; avaricious; stingy; sordid; niggardly

misery.definition: Great unhappiness; extreme pain of body or mind; wretchedness; distress; woe

misfall.definition: To befall, as ill luck; to happen to unluckily

misfeasance.definition: A trespass; a wrong arising from an overt act; the improper doing of an act which a person might lawfully do

misfeign.definition: To feign with an evil design

misfit.definition: The act or the state of fitting badly; as, a misfit in making a coat; a ludicrous misfit
Something that fits badly, as a garment
A person who does not fit in comfortably with the surrounding situation or society; one who cannot conform or adjust to the circumstances in which he lives

misform.definition: To make in an ill form

misfortune.definition: Bad fortune or luck; calamity; an evil accident; disaster; mishap; mischance
To happen unluckily or unfortunately; to miscarry; to fail

misgive.definition: Specifically: To give doubt and apprehension to, instead of confidence and courage; to impart fear to; to make irresolute; -- usually said of the mind or heart, and followed by the objective personal pronoun
To give out doubt and apprehension; to be fearful or irresolute

misgiving.definition: Evil premonition; doubt; distrust; a feeling of apprehension; -- used commonly in the plural

misgovern.definition: To govern badly; as, to misgovern a country

misgoverned.definition: Ill governed, as a people; ill directed

misgrowth.definition: Bad growth; an unnatural or abnormal growth

misguide.definition: To guide wrongly; to lead astray; as, to misguide the understanding

mishandle.definition: To handle ill or wrongly; to maltreat

mishap.definition: Evil accident; ill luck; misfortune; mischance

mishmash.definition: A hodgepodge or hotchpotch; a confused jumble

mishna.definition: A collection or digest of Jewish traditions and explanations of Scripture, forming the text of the Talmud

mishnic.definition: Of or pertaining to the Mishna

misimprove.definition: To use for a bad purpose; to abuse; to misuse; as, to misimprove time, talents, advantages, etc

misimprovement.definition: Ill use or employment; use for a bad purpose

misincline.definition: To cause to have a wrong inclination or tendency; to affect wrongly

misinform.definition: To give untrue information to; to inform wrongly
To give untrue information; (with against) to calumniate

misinformer.definition: One who gives untrue or incorrect information

misinterpret.definition: To interpret erroneously; to understand or to explain in a wrong sense

misinterpretable.definition: Capable of being misinterpreted; liable to be misunderstood

misinterpretation.definition: The act of interpreting erroneously; a mistaken interpretation

misjoinder.definition: An incorrect union of parties or of causes of action in a procedure, criminal or civil

misjudge.definition: To judge erroneously or unjustly; to err in judgment; to misconstrue

miskindle.definition: To kindle amiss; to inflame to a bad purpose; to excite wrongly

misknow.definition: To have a mistaken notion of or about

mislactation.definition: Defective flow or vitiated condition of the milk

mislay.definition: To lay in a wrong place; to ascribe to a wrong source
To lay in a place not recollected; to misplace; to lose

misle.definition: To rain in very fine drops, like a thick mist; to mizzle; to drizzle
A fine rain; a thick mist; a mizzle; a drizzle

mislead.definition: To lead into a wrong way or path; to lead astray; to guide into error; to cause to mistake; to deceive

mislight.definition: To deceive or lead astray with a false light

mislike.definition: To dislike; to disapprove of; to have aversion to; as, to mislike a man

misly.definition: Raining in very small drops; drizzling

mismake.definition: To make or form amiss; to spoil in making

mismanage.definition: To manage ill or improperly; as, to mismanage public affairs

mismanagement.definition: Wrong or bad management; as, he failed through mismagement

mismatched.definition: Matched unsuitably; grouped into pairs or sets with incompatible characteristics
Of very unequal ability; -- of contestants in a contest.  The less able contestant is said to be overmatched or outclassed

mismate.definition: To mate wrongly or unsuitably; to mismatch; as, to mismate gloves or shoes; a mismated couple

mismeter.definition: To give the wrong meter to, as to a line of verse

misname.definition: To call by the wrong name; to give a wrong or inappropriate name to

misnomer.definition: The misnaming of a person in a legal instrument, as in a complaint or indictment; any misnaming of a person or thing; a wrong or inapplicable name or title

misnurture.definition: To nurture or train wrongly; as, to misnurture children

misobserve.definition: To observe inaccurately; to mistake in observing

misobserver.definition: One who misobserves; one who fails to observe properly

misogynous.definition: Hating women; having deep-seated distrust of women; -- used of men

misology.definition: Hatred of argument or discussion; hatred of enlightenment

misorder.definition: To order ill; to manage erroneously; to conduct badly

mispersuasion.definition: A false persuasion; wrong notion or opinion

misplace.definition: To put in a wrong place; to set or place on an improper or unworthy object; as, he misplaced his confidence
To place in a location that one does not recall; to  mislay; to lose

misplacement.definition: The act of misplacing, or the state of being misplaced

mispoint.definition: To point improperly; to punctuate wrongly

misprint.definition: To print wrongly; to make a mistake in printing
A mistake in printing; a deviation from the copy; as, a book full of misprints.  Misprints are sometimes noted and corrected in a list of corrigenda distributed with a book

misprision.definition: The act of misprising; misapprehension; misconception; mistake

misprofess.definition: To make a false profession; to make pretensions to skill which is not possessed
To make a false profession of

misproportion.definition: To give wrong or unesthetic proportions to; to join without due proportion; as, the legs were misrpoportioned to the body

misread.definition: To read amiss; to misunderstand in reading

misrecollect.definition: To have an erroneous remembrance of; to suppose erroneously that one recollects

misregulate.definition: To regulate wrongly or imperfectly; to fail to regulate

misremember.definition: To mistake in remembering; not to remember correctly

misrender.definition: To render wrongly; to translate or recite wrongly

misrepeat.definition: To repeat wrongly; to give a wrong version of

misreport.definition: To report erroneously; to give an incorrect account of
An erroneous report; a false or incorrect account given

misrepresent.definition: To represent incorrectly (almost always, unfavorably); to give a false or erroneous representation of, either maliciously, ignorantly, or carelessly
To make an incorrect or untrue representation

misrepresentation.definition: Untrue representation; false or incorrect statement or account; -- usually unfavorable to the thing represented; as, a misrepresentation of a person's motives

misrepresentative.definition: Tending to convey a wrong impression; misrepresenting

misrepute.definition: To have in wrong estimation; to repute or estimate erroneously

misrule.definition: The act, or the result, of misruling

miss.definition: A title of courtesy prefixed to the name of a girl or a woman who has not been married. See Mistress, 5
A young unmarried woman or a girl; as, she is a miss of sixteen
In the game of three-card loo, an extra hand, dealt on the table, which may be substituted for the hand dealt to a player

To fail of hitting, reaching, getting, finding, seeing, hearing, etc.; as, to miss the mark one shoots at; to miss the train by being late; to miss opportunites of getting knowledge; to miss the point or meaning of something said
To omit; to fail to have or to do; to get without; to dispense with; -- now seldom applied to persons
To discover the absence or omission of; to feel the want of; to mourn the loss of; to want; as, to miss an absent loved one
To fail to hit; to fly wide; to deviate from the true direction
To fail to obtain, learn, or find; -- with of
To be absent, deficient, or wanting
The act of missing; failure to hit, reach, find, obtain, etc

missa.definition: The service or sacrifice of the Mass

missal.definition: The book containing the service of the Mass for the entire year; a Mass book
Of or pertaining to the Mass, or to a missal or Mass book

missay.definition: To speak evil of; to slander

misshape.definition: To shape ill; to give an ill or unnatural from to; to deform

misshapen.definition: Having a bad or ugly form

missheathed.definition: Sheathed by mistake; wrongly sheathed; sheathed in a wrong place

missile.definition: Capable of being thrown; adapted for hurling or to be projected from the hand, or from any instrument or engine{2}, so as to strike an object at a distance
A weapon thrown or projected or intended to be projected, as a lance, an arrow, or a bullet
A rocket-propelled device designed to fly through the air and deliver a warhead of explosive materials to a target

missing.definition: Absent from the place where it was expected to be found; lost; lacking; wanting; not present when called or looked for

mission.definition: The act of sending, or the state of being sent; a being sent or delegated by authority, with certain powers for transacting business; comission
That with which a messenger or agent is charged; an errand; business or duty on which one is sent; a commission
Persons sent; any number of persons appointed to perform any service; a delegation; an embassy; as, the Russian mission to the United Nations
An assotiation or organization of missionaries; a station or residence of missionaries
An organization for worship and work, dependent on one or more churches
A course of extraordinary sermons and services at a particular place and time for the special purpose of quickening the faith and zeal participants, and of converting unbelievers

missionary.definition: One who is sent on a mission; especially, one sent to propagate religion
Of or pertaining to missions; as, a missionary meeting; a missionary fund

missioner.definition: A missionary; an envoy; one who conducts a mission. See Mission, n., 6

missis.definition: A mistress; a wife; -- so used by the illiterate

missish.definition: Like a miss; prim; affected; sentimental

mississippian.definition: A geological period extending from from 310 million to 345 million years ago; it was associated with an increase of land areas, the presence of primitive ammonites, and emergence of winged insects; called also Missippian period and Lower Carboniferous period
synonyms: Syn. -- Missippian period, Lower Carboniferous, Lower Carboniferous period.

missit.definition: To sit badly or imperfectly upon; to misbecome

missive.definition: Specially sent; intended or prepared to be sent; as, a letter missive
That which is sent; a writing containing a message
One who is sent; a messenger

missound.definition: To sound wrongly; to utter or pronounce incorrectly

misspend.definition: To spend amiss or for wrong purposes; to squander; to waste; as, to misspend time or money

misstate.definition: To state wrongly; as, to misstate a question in debate

misstayed.definition: Having missed stays; -- said of a ship

misstep.definition: A wrong step; an error of conduct
To take a wrong step; to go astray

missy.definition: An affectionate, or contemptuous, form of miss; a young girl; a miss

mist.definition: Visible watery vapor suspended in the atmosphere, at or near the surface of the earth; fog
Coarse, watery vapor, floating or falling in visible particles, approaching the form of rain; as, Scotch mist
Hence, anything which dims or darkens, and obscures or intercepts vision
To cloud; to cover with mist; to dim
To rain in very fine drops; as, it mists

mistakable.definition: Liable to be mistaken; capable of being misconceived

mistake.definition: To take in a wrong sense; to misunderstand misapprehend, or misconceive; as, to mistake a remark; to mistake one's meaning
To substitute in thought or perception; as, to mistake one person for another
To have a wrong idea of in respect of character, qualities, etc.; to misjudge
To err in knowledge, perception, opinion, or judgment; to commit an unintentional error
An apprehending wrongly; a misconception; a misunderstanding; a fault in opinion or judgment; an unintentional error of conduct
Misconception, error, which when non-negligent may be ground for rescinding a contract, or for refusing to perform it

mistaken.definition: Being in error; judging wrongly; having a wrong opinion or a misconception; as, a mistaken man; he is mistaken
Erroneous; wrong; as, a mistaken notion

mistaught.definition: Wrongly taught; as, a mistaught youth

misteach.definition: To teach wrongly; to instruct erroneously

mistemper.definition: To temper ill; to disorder; as, to mistemper one's head

mister.definition: A title of courtesy prefixed to the name of a man or youth. It is usually written in the abbreviated form Mr
To address or mention by the title Mr.; as, he mistered me in a formal way
To be needful or of use

misterm.definition: To call by a wrong name; to miscall

mistful.definition: Clouded with, or as with, mist

misthink.definition: To have erroneous thoughts or judgment of; to think ill of

misthrive.definition: To thrive poorly; to be not thrifty or prosperous

mistic.definition: A kind of small sailing vessel used in the Mediterranean.  It is rigged partly like a xebec, and partly like a felucca

mistide.definition: To happen or come to pass unfortunately; also, to suffer evil fortune

mistigris.definition: A variety of the game of poker in which the joker is used, and called mistigris or mistigri

mistime.definition: To time wrongly; not to adapt to the time

mistiming.definition: The act or process of assigning something to a time when it could not have existed or occurred

mistitle.definition: To call by a wrong title

mistle.definition: To fall in very fine drops, as rain; to drizzle

mistletoe.definition: A parasitic evergreen plant of Europe (Viscum album), bearing a glutinous fruit.  When found upon the oak, where it is rare, it was an object of superstitious regard among the Druids.  A bird lime is prepared from its fruit

mistook.definition: imp. & obs. p. p. of Mistake

mistral.definition: A violent and cold northwest wind experienced in the Mediterranean provinces of France, etc

mistransport.definition: To carry away or mislead wrongfully, as by passion

mistress.definition: A woman having power, authority, or ownership; a woman who exercises authority, is chief, etc.; the female head of a family, a school, etc
A woman well skilled in anything, or having the mastery over it
A woman regarded with love and devotion; she who has command over one's heart; a beloved object; a sweetheart

A woman filling the place, but without the rights, of a wife; a woman having an ongoing usually exclusive sexual relationship with a man, who may provide her with financial support in return; a concubine; a loose woman with whom one consorts habitually; as, both his wife and his mistress attended his funeral
A title of courtesy formerly prefixed to the name of a woman, married or unmarried, but now superseded by the contracted forms, Mrs., for a married, and Miss, for an unmarried, woman
The old name of the jack at bowls
To wait upon a mistress; to be courting

mistressship.definition: Ladyship, a style of address; -- with the personal pronoun

mistrial.definition: A false or erroneous trial; a trial which has no result; a trial which comes to no conclusion, such as a criminal trial which does not produce a unanimous verdict of the jurors

mistrust.definition: Want of confidence or trust; suspicion; distrust
To regard with jealousy or suspicion; to suspect; to doubt the integrity of; to distrust
To forebode as near, or likely to occur; to surmise

mistrustful.definition: Having or causing mistrust, suspicions, or forebodings

mistura.definition: A mingled compound in which different ingredients are contained in a liquid state; a mixture. See Mixture, n., 4

misty.definition: Accompanied with mist; characterized by the presence of mist; obscured by, or overspread with, mist; as, a misty morning; misty weather; misty mountains; a misty atmosphere
Obscured as if by mist; dim; obscure; clouded; as, misty sight; to peer into the misty future

misunderstand.definition: To misconceive; to mistake; to miscomprehend; to take in a wrong sense

misunderstanding.definition: Mistake of the meaning; error; misconception
Disagreement; difference of opinion; dissension; quarrel

misurato.definition: Measured; -- a direction to perform a passage in strict or measured time

misuse.definition: To treat or use improperly; to use to a bad purpose; to misapply; as, to misuse one's talents
Wrong use; misapplication; erroneous or improper use

misuser.definition: Unlawful use of a right; use in excess of, or varying from, one's right

misvalue.definition: To value wrongly or too little; to undervalue

miswander.definition: To wander in a wrong path; to stray; to go astray

misween.definition: To ween amiss; to misjudge; to distrust; to be mistaken

miswend.definition: To go wrong; to go astray

misword.definition: To word wrongly; as, to misword a message, or a sentence
A word wrongly spoken; a cross word

misworship.definition: Wrong or false worship; mistaken practices in religion

misy.definition: An impure yellow sulphate of iron; yellow copperas or copiapite

mite.definition: A minute arachnid, of the order Acarina, of which there are many species; as, the dust mite, cheese mite, sugar mite, harvest mite, three-toed spider mite, etc. See Acarina
A small coin formerly circulated in England, rated at about a third of a farthing.  The name is also applied to a small coin used in Palestine in the time of Christ
A small weight; one twentieth of a grain
Anything very small; a minute object; a very little quantity or particle

mitella.definition: A genus of low slender herbs of North America and Northeast Asia having flowers with trifid or pinnatifid petals

miter.definition: A covering for the head, worn on solemn occasions by bishops and other church dignitaries.  It has been made in many forms, the present form being a lofty cap with two points or peaks
The surface forming the beveled end or edge of a piece where a miter joint is made; also, a joint formed or a junction effected by two beveled ends or edges; a miter joint
A sort of base money or coin
To place a miter upon; to adorn with a miter
To match together, as two pieces of molding or brass rule on a line bisecting the angle of junction; to fit together in a miter joint
To bevel the ends or edges of, for the purpose of matching together at an angle
To meet and match together, as two pieces of molding, on a line bisecting the angle of junction

miterwort.definition: Any plant of the genus Mitella, -- slender, perennial herbs with a pod slightly resembling a bishop's miter; bishop's cap

mithra.definition: The sun god of the ancient Persians; the god of light and truth

mithraism.definition: The ancient Persian religion which worshiped Mithra; it was popular among Romans during first three centuries a. d

mithridate.definition: An antidote against poison, or a composition in form of an electuary, supposed to serve either as a remedy or a preservative against poison; an alexipharmic; -- so called from King Mithridates, its reputed inventor

mithridatic.definition: Of or pertaining to King Mithridates, or to a mithridate

mitigable.definition: Admitting of mitigation; that may be mitigated

mitigate.definition: To make less severe, intense, harsh, rigorous, painful, etc.; to soften; to meliorate; to alleviate; to diminish; to lessen; as, to mitigate heat or cold; to mitigate grief
To make mild and accessible; to mollify; -- applied to persons

mitigating.definition: serving to reduce blame; -- of situations; as, mitigating factors; mitigating circumstances.  Opposite of aggravating

mitigation.definition: The act of mitigating, or the state of being mitigated; abatement or diminution of anything painful, harsh, severe, afflictive, or calamitous; as, the mitigation of pain, grief, rigor, severity, punishment, or penalty

mitigator.definition: One who, or that which, mitigates

mitigatory.definition: Tending to mitigate or alleviate; mitigative

miting.definition: A little one; -- used as a term of endearment

mitis casting.definition: A process, invented by P. Ostberg, for producing malleable iron castings by melting wrought iron, to which from 0.05 to 0.1 per cent of aluminum is added to lower the melting point, usually in a petroleum furnace, keeping the molten metal at the bubbling point until it becomes quiet, and then pouring the molten metal into a mold lined with a special mixture consisting essentially of molasses and ground burnt fire clay; also, a casting made by this process; -- called also wrought-iron casting
