mutinous.definition: Disposed to mutiny; in a state of mutiny; characterized by mutiny; seditious; insubordinate

mutiny.definition: Insurrection against constituted authority, particularly military or naval authority; concerted revolt against the rules of discipline or the lawful commands of a superior officer; hence, generally, forcible resistance to rightful authority; insubordination

To rise against, or refuse to obey, lawful authority in military or naval service; to excite, or to be guilty of, mutiny or mutinous conduct; to revolt against one's superior officer, or any rightful authority
To fall into strife; to quarrel

mutism.definition: The condition, state, or habit of being mute, or without speech

mutoscope.definition: A simple form of moving-picture machine in which the series of views, exhibiting the successive phases of a scene, are printed on paper and mounted around the periphery of a wheel.  The rotation of the wheel brings them rapidly into sight, one after another, and the blended effect gives a semblance of motion

mutt.definition: An dog that is of inferior quality or of mixed breed

mutter.definition: To utter words indistinctly or with a low voice and lips partly closed; esp., to utter indistinct complaints or angry expressions; to grumble; to growl
To sound with a low, rumbling noise
To utter with imperfect articulations, or with a low voice; as, to mutter threats

mutteringly.definition: With a low voice and indistinct articulation; in a muttering manner

muttonfish.definition: A fish (Lutjanus analis) similar to and often marketed as “red snapper”

muttonhead.definition: A stupid or foolish person; a dolt; a numbskull; a blockhead; -- disparaging and offensive.  These words are used to express a low opinion of someone's intelligence
synonyms: Syn. -- dunce, dunderhead, numskull, blockhead, bonehead, lunkhead, hammerhead, knucklehead, loggerhead, shithead, fuckhead.

muttony.definition: Like mutton; having a flavor of mutton

mutual.definition: Reciprocally acting or related; reciprocally receiving and giving; reciprocally given and received; reciprocal; interchanged; as, a mutual love, advantage, assistance, aversion, etc
Possessed, experienced, or done by two or more persons or things at the same time; common; joint; as, mutual happiness; a mutual effort

mutual savings bank.definition: a state-chartered savings bank owned by its depositors and managed by a board of trustees.  Abbreviated MSB

mutualism.definition: The doctrine of mutual dependence as the condition of individual and social welfare

mutualist.definition: One practising or advocating the doctrine of mutualism

mutuality.definition: The quality of correlation; reciprocation; interchange; interaction; interdependence

mutuary.definition: One who borrows personal chattels which are to be consumed by him, and which he is to return or repay in kind

mutuation.definition: The act of borrowing or exchanging

mutule.definition: A projecting block worked under the corona of the Doric corice, in the same situation as the modillion of the Corinthian and Composite orders. See Illust. of Gutta

mux.definition: To mix in an untidy and offensive way; to make a mess of

muzarab.definition: One of a denomination of Christians formerly living under the government of the Moors in Spain, and having a liturgy and ritual of their own

muzarabic.definition: Of or pertaining to Muzarabs; as, the Muzarabic liturgy

muzziness.definition: The state or quality of being muzzy

muzzle.definition: The projecting mouth and nose of a quadruped, as of a horse; a snout
The mouth of a thing; the end for entrance or discharge; as, the muzzle of a gun
A fastening or covering (as a band or cage) for the mouth of an animal, to prevent eating or vicious biting

To bind the mouth of; to fasten the mouth of, so as to prevent biting or eating; hence, figuratively, to bind; to sheathe; to restrain from speech or action; as, the dictator muzzled all the newspapers
To fondle with the closed mouth
To bring the mouth or muzzle near

muzzle-loader.definition: A firearm which receives its charge through the muzzle, as distinguished from one which is loaded at the breech

muzzle-loading.definition: Receiving its charge through the muzzle; as, a muzzle-loading rifle

mvp.definition: most valuable player; the player judged to be the most important to the sport, also the name of the award given to that player

mx.definition: The symbol for the maxwell, a cgs unit of magnetic flux

my.definition: Of or belonging to me; -- used always attributively; as, my body; my book; -- mine is used in the predicate; as, the book is mine. See Mine

mya.definition: A genus of bivalve mollusks, including the common long, or soft-shelled, clam

myacidae.definition: A natural family of soft-shell clams

myadestes.definition: A genus of birds including  the solitaires, thrushes noted for their beautiful songs

myalgia.definition: Pain in the muscles; muscular rheumatism or neuralgia

myall wood.definition: A durable, fragrant, and dark-colored Australian wood, used by the natives for spears. It is obtained from the small tree Acacia homolophylla

myaria.definition: A division of bivalve mollusks of which the common clam (Mya) is the type

mycelium.definition: The white threads or filamentous growth from which a mushroom or fungus is developed; the so-called mushroom spawn

mycetes.definition: A genus of South American monkeys, including the howlers. See Howler, 2, and Illust

mycetozoa.definition: The Myxomycetes; -- so called by those who regard them as a class of animals

mycobacteria.definition: A group of rod-shaped bacteria, some saprophytic or causing diseases

mycobacterium.definition: Any of various rod-shaped bacteria, some saprophytic or causing diseases

mycoderma.definition: One of the forms in which bacteria group themselves; a more or less thick layer of motionless but living bacteria, formed by the bacteria uniting on the surface of the fluid in which they are developed.  This production differs from the zoogloea stage of bacteria by not having the intermediary mucous substance
A genus of microorganisms of which the acetic ferment (Mycoderma aceti), which converts alcoholic fluids into vinegar, is a representative.  Cf. Mother

mycologic.definition: Of or relating to mycology, or the fungi

mycologist.definition: One who is versed in, or who studies, mycology

mycology.definition: That branch of botanical science which relates to the mushrooms and other fungi

mycomelic.definition: Pertaining to, or designating, a complex nitrogenous acid of the alloxan group, obtained as a honey-yellow powder.  Its solutions have a gelatinous consistency

mycoprotein.definition: The protoplasmic matter of which bacteria are composed

mycose.definition: A variety of sugar, isomeric with sucrose and obtained from certain lichens and fungi.  Called also trehalose

mycothrix.definition: The chain of micrococci formed by the division of the micrococci in multiplication

mycteria.definition: A genus of birds including certain of the wood ibises, including the endangered Mycteria americana; it is sometimes assigned to a subfamily Mycteriinae

mydaleine.definition: A toxic alkaloid (ptomaine) obtained from putrid flesh and from herring brines.  As a poison it is said to execute profuse diarrhoea, vomiting, and intestinal inflammation

mydatoxin.definition: A poisonous amido acid, C6H13NO2, separated by Brieger from decaying horseflesh. In physiological action, it is similar to curare

mydriasis.definition: A long-continued or excessive dilatation of the pupil of the eye

myelencephalic.definition: Of or pertaining to the myelencephalon; cerebro-spinal

myelencephalon.definition: The brain and spinal cord; the cerebro-spinal axis.  Sometimes abbreviated to myelencephal

myelencephalous.definition: Of or pertaining to the Myelencephala

myelin.definition: A soft white substance constituting the medullary sheaths of nerve fibers, and composed mainly of cholesterin, lecithin, cerebrin, protein, and some fat

myelitis.definition: Inflammation of the spinal marrow or its membranes

myelocoele.definition: The central canal of the spinal cord

myelogenic.definition: Derived from, or pertaining to, the bone marrow

myeloid.definition: Resembling marrow in appearance or consistency; as, a myeloid tumor

myeloidin.definition: A substance, present in the protoplasm of the retinal epithelium cells, and resembling, if not identical with, the substance (myelin) forming the medullary sheaths of nerve fibers

myelon.definition: The spinal cord. (Sometimes abbrev. to myel.)

myelonal.definition: Of or pertaining to the myelon; as, the myelonal, or spinal, nerves

myeloplax.definition: One of the huge multinucleated cells found in the marrow of bone and occasionally in other parts; a giant cell. See Osteoclast

mygale.definition: A genus of very large hairy spiders of the family Ctenizidae, having four lungs and only four spinnerets.  They do not spin webs, but usually construct tubes in the earth, which are often furnished with a trapdoor.  The South American bird spider (Mygale avicularia), and the crab spider, or matoutou (Mygale cancerides) are among the largest species.  They are also called trapdoor spiders.  Some of the species are erroneously called tarantulas, as the Texas tarantula (Mygale Hentzii)

mykiss.definition: A salmon (Salmo mykiss, syn. Salmo purpuratus) marked with black spots and a red throat, found in most of the rivers from Alaska to the Colorado River, and in Siberia; -- called also black-spotted trout, cutthroat trout, and redthroat trout

mylitta.definition: The goddess of love and fertility and war; also called Ishtar; the counterpart of Ashtoreth and Astarte

mylodon.definition: An extinct genus of large slothlike American edentates, allied to Megatherium

mylodontidae.definition: A natural family of extinct South American edentates

mylohyoid.definition: Pertaining to, or in the region of, the lower jaw and the hyoid apparatus; as, the mylohyoid nerve

myna.definition: Any one of numerous species of Asiatic starlings of the genera Acridotheres, Sturnopastor, Sturnia, Gracula, and allied genera.  In habits they resemble the European starlings, and like them are often caged and taught to talk.  See Hill myna, under Hill, and Mino bird

mynchery.definition: A nunnery; -- a term still applied to the ruins of certain nunneries in England

mynheer.definition: The Dutch equivalent of Mr. or Sir; hence, a Dutchman

myo-.definition: A combining form of Gr. &unr_;, &unr_;, a muscle; as, myograph, myochrome

myocardial.definition: Of or pertaining to the myocardium

myocardium.definition: The main substance of the muscular wall of the heart inclosed between the epicardium and endocardium

myochrome.definition: A colored albuminous substance in the serum from red-colored muscles.  It is identical with hemoglobin

myodynamics.definition: The department of physiology which deals with the principles of muscular contraction; the exercise of muscular force or contraction

myodynamometer.definition: An instrument for measuring the muscular strength of man or of other animals; a dynamometer

myoepithelial.definition: Derived from epithelial cells and destined to become a part of the muscular system; -- applied to structural elements in certain embryonic forms
Having the characteristics of both muscle and epithelium; as, the myoepithelial cells of the hydra

myogalid.definition: One of the Myogalodae, a family of Insectivora, including the desman, and allied species

myograph.definition: An instrument for determining and recording the different phases, as the intensity, velocity, etc., of a muscular contraction

myography.definition: The description of muscles, including the study of muscular contraction by the aid of registering apparatus, as by some form of myograph; myology

myohaematin.definition: A red-colored respiratory pigment found associated with hemoglobin in the muscle tissue of a large number of animals, both vertebrate and invertebrate

myoid.definition: Composed of, or resembling, muscular fiber

myolin.definition: The essential material of muscle fibers

myology.definition: That part of anatomy which treats of muscles

myoma.definition: A tumor consisting of muscular tissue

myomancy.definition: Divination by the movements of mice

myomorpha.definition: An extensive group of rodents which includes the rats, mice, jerboas, and many allied forms

myopathia.definition: Any affection of the muscles or muscular system

myope.definition: A person having myopia; a myops

myophan.definition: A contractile striated layer found in the bodies and stems of certain Infusoria

myopia.definition: Nearsightedness; shortsightedness; a condition of the eye in which the rays from distant object are brought to a focus before they reach the retina, and hence form an indistinct image; while the rays from very near objects are normally converged so as to produce a distinct image.  It is corrected by the use of a concave lens

myopic.definition: Pertaining to, or affected with, or characterized by, myopia; nearsighted

myopsis.definition: The appearance of muscae volitantes. See Muscae volitantes, under Musca

myosin.definition: A protein present in muscle, serving as the principle contractile protein in muscle contraction

myosis.definition: Long-continued contraction of the pupil of the eye

myosotis.definition: A genus of plants. See Mouse-ear

myotic.definition: Producing myosis, or contraction of the pupil of the eye, as opium, calabar bean, etc

myotome.definition: A muscular segment; one of the zones into which the muscles of the trunk, especially in fishes, are divided; a myocomma

myotomic.definition: Of or pertaining to a myotome or myotomes

myotomy.definition: The dissection, or that part of anatomy which treats of the dissection, of muscles

myrcia.definition: A large genus of tropical American trees and shrubs, nearly related to the true myrtles (Myrtus), from which they differ in having very few seeds in each berry

myria-.definition: A prefix, esp. in the metric system, indicating ten thousand, ten thousand times; as, myriameter

myriacanthous.definition: Having numerous spines, as certain fishes

myriad.definition: The number of ten thousand; ten thousand persons or things
An immense number; a very great many; an indefinitely large number
Consisting of a very great, but indefinite, number; as, myriad stars

myriagram.definition: A metric weight, consisting of ten thousand grams or ten kilograms.  It is equal to 22.046 lbs. avoirdupois

myrialiter.definition: A metric measure of capacity, containing ten thousand liters.  It is equal to 2641.7 wine gallons

myriameter.definition: A metric measure of length, containing ten thousand meters.  It is equal to 6.2137 miles

myriapoda.definition: A class, or subclass, of arthropods, related to the hexapod insects, from which they differ in having the body made up of numerous similar segments, nearly all of which bear true jointed legs.  They have one pair of antennae, three pairs of mouth organs, and numerous tracheae, similar to those of true insects.  The larvae, when first hatched, often have but three pairs of legs. See Centiped, Galleyworm, Milliped

myriarch.definition: A captain or commander of ten thousand men

myriare.definition: A measure of surface in the metric system containing ten thousand ares, or one million square meters.  It is equal to about 247.1 acres

myrica.definition: A widely dispersed genus of shrubs and trees, usually with aromatic foliage.  It includes the bayberry or wax myrtle, the sweet gale, and the North American sweet fern, so called

myricin.definition: A silky, crystalline, waxy substance, forming the less soluble part of beeswax, and regarded as a palmitate of a higher alcohol of the paraffin series; -- called also myricyl alcohol

myricyl.definition: A hypothetical radical regarded as the essential residue of myricin; -- called also melissyl

myriological.definition: Of or relating to a myriologue

myriologist.definition: One who composes or sings a myriologue

myriologue.definition: An extemporaneous funeral song, composed and sung by a woman on the death of a friend

myriophyllous.definition: Having an indefinitely great or countless number of leaves

myriorama.definition: A picture made up of several smaller pictures, drawn upon separate pieces in such a manner as to admit of combination in many different ways, thus producing a great variety of scenes or landscapes

myristic.definition: Pertaining to, or derived from, the nutmeg (Myristica).  Specifically, designating an acid (C14H28O2) found in nutmeg oil and otoba fat, and extracted as a white crystalline waxy substance

myristin.definition: The myristate of glycerin, -- found as a vegetable fat in nutmeg butter, etc

myristone.definition: The ketone of myristic acid, obtained as a white crystalline substance

myrmecophaga.definition: The type genus of the Myrmecophagidae; the South American ant bear

myrmecophagidae.definition: A natural family of New World anteaters

myrmecophagous.definition: feeding on ants but usually not living with them

myrmecophile.definition: An organism such as an insect that habitually shares the nest of a species of ant

myrmecophilous.definition: Associated with, or benefitted by ants through sharing their nest

myrmecophyte.definition: A plant that affords shelter and food to certain species of ants which live in symbiotic relations with it. Special adaptations for this purpose exist; thus, Acacia spadicigera has large hollows thorns, and species of Cecropia have stem cavities

myrmecophytic.definition: Of or pertaining to a myrmecophyte

myrmeleon.definition: The type genus of the Myrmeleontidae, including the antlions

myrmeleontidae.definition: A natural family of the order Neuroptera, including the antlions

myrmicine.definition: Of or pertaining to Myrmica, a genus of ants including the small house ant (Myrmica molesta), and many others

myrmidon.definition: One of a fierce tribe or troop who accompanied Achilles, their king, to the Trojan war
A soldier or a subordinate civil officer who executes cruel orders of a superior without protest or pity; -- sometimes applied to bailiffs, constables, etc

myrmotherine.definition: Feeding upon ants; -- said of certain birds

myrobalan.definition: A dried astringent fruit much resembling a prune.  It contains tannin, and was formerly used in medicine, but is now chiefly used in tanning and dyeing.  Myrobolans are produced by various species of Terminalia of the East Indies, and of Spondias of South America

myronic.definition: Pertaining to, or obtained from, mustard; -- used specifically to designate a glucoside called myronic acid, found in mustard seed

myropolist.definition: One who sells unguents or perfumery

myrosin.definition: An enzyme, resembling diastase, found in mustard seeds

myroxylon.definition: A genus of leguminous trees of tropical America, the different species of which yield balsamic products, among which are balsam of Peru, and balsam of Tolu.  The species were formerly referred to Myrospermum

myrrh.definition: A gum resin, usually of a yellowish brown or amber color, of an aromatic odor, and a bitter, slightly pungent taste.  It is valued for its odor and for its medicinal properties.  It exudes from the bark of a shrub of Abyssinia and Arabia, the Commiphora Myrrha (syn. Balsamodendron Myrrha) of the family Burseraceae, or from the Commiphora abyssinica.  The myrrh of the Bible is supposed to have been partly the gum above named, and partly the exudation of species of Cistus, or rockrose

myrrhic.definition: Of, pertaining to, or obtained from, myrrh

myrtaceae.definition: A natural family of trees and shrubs yielding fragrant oils, including the myrtles, eucalyptus, clove, allspice, and guava; the myrtle family

myrtaceous.definition: Of, pertaining to, or resembling, a large and important natural family of trees and shrubs (Myrtaceae of the order Myrtales), of which the myrtle (Myrtus) is the type.  It includes the genera Eucalyptus, Pimenta, Lechythis, and about seventy more

myrtales.definition: A natural order of trees and shrubs including the myrtle family, Myrtaceae; Combretaceae; Elaeagnaceae; Haloragidaceae; Melastomaceae; Lecythidaceae; Lythraceae; Rhizophoraceae; Onagraceae; Lecythidaceae; and Punicaceae
synonyms: Syn. -- order Myrtales, Thymelaeales, order Thymelaeales.

myrtiform.definition: Resembling myrtle or myrtle berries; having the form of a myrtle leaf

myrtillocactus.definition: A small genus of arborescent cacti of Mexico and Central America

myrtle.definition: A species of the genus Myrtus, especially Myrtus communis. The common myrtle has a shrubby, upright stem, eight or ten feet high. Its branches form a close, full head, thickly covered with ovate or lanceolate evergreen leaves.  It has solitary axillary white or rosy flowers, followed by black several-seeded berries.  The ancients considered it sacred to Venus.  The flowers, leaves, and berries are used variously in perfumery and as a condiment, and the beautifully mottled wood is used in turning

myrtus.definition: The type genus of the Myrtaceae

myself.definition: I or me in person; -- used for emphasis, my own self or person; as I myself will do it; I have done it myself; -- used also instead of me, as the object of the first person of a reflexive verb, without emphasis; as, I will defend myself

mysidacea.definition: An order of crustaceans including the opossum shrimp

mysidae.definition: A natural family of small shrimplike crustaceans

mysis.definition: A genus of small schizopod shrimps found both in fresh and salt water; the opossum shrimps.  One species inhabits the Great Lakes of North America, and is largely eaten by the whitefish.  The marine species form part of the food of right whales

mystacal.definition: Of or pertaining to the upper lip, or mustache

mystagogic.definition: Of or pertaining to interpretation of mysteries or to mystagogue; of the nature of mystagogy

mystagogue.definition: One who interprets mysteries, especially of a religious kind
One who keeps and shows church relics

mystagogy.definition: The doctrines, principles, or practice of a mystagogue; interpretation of mysteries

mysterious.definition: Of or pertaining to mystery; containing a mystery; difficult or impossible to understand; inexplicable; obscure; not revealed or explained; enigmatical; incomprehensible

mysteriousness.definition: The state or quality of being mysterious

mysterize.definition: To make mysterious; to make a mystery of

mystery.definition: A profound secret; something wholly unknown, or something kept cautiously concealed, and therefore exciting curiosity or wonder; something which has not been or can not be explained; hence, specifically, that which is beyond human comprehension
A kind of secret religious celebration, to which none were admitted except those who had been initiated by certain preparatory ceremonies; -- usually plural; as, the Eleusinian mysteries
The consecrated elements in the eucharist
Anything artfully made difficult; an enigma
A trade; a handicraft; hence, any business with which one is usually occupied

A dramatic representation of a Scriptural subject, often some event in the life of Christ; a dramatic composition of this character; as, the Chester Mysteries, consisting of dramas acted by various craft associations in that city in the early part of the 14th century

mystic.definition: Remote from or beyond human comprehension; baffling human understanding; unknowable; obscure; mysterious
Importing or implying mysticism; involving some secret meaning; allegorical; emblematical; as, a mystic dance; mystic Babylon
employing mysticism; as, mystical intuition; mystical explanations; -- contrasted to logical, rational, analytical
One given to mysticism; one who holds mystical views, interpretations, etc.; especially, in ecclesiastical history, one who professed mysticism. See Mysticism

mysticete.definition: Any right whale, or whalebone whale. See Cetacea

mysticeti.definition: A suborder including baleen whales: right whales; rorquals; blue whales; and humpbacks

mysticism.definition: The doctrine of the Mystics, who professed a pure, sublime, and wholly disinterested devotion, and maintained that they had direct intercourse with the divine Spirit, and aquired a knowledge of God and of spiritual things unattainable by the natural intellect, and such as can not be analyzed or explained
The doctrine that the ultimate elements or principles of knowledge or belief are gained by an act or process akin to feeling or faith

mystification.definition: The act of mystifying, or the state of being mystied; also, something designed to, or that does, mystify

mystify.definition: To involve in mystery; to make obscure or difficult to understand; as, to mystify a passage of Scripture
To perplex the mind of; to puzzle; to impose upon the credulity of; to baffle; as, to mystify an opponent

mystique.definition: An aura of reverence or mystery stemming from  feelings of high value or interest or meaning surrounding a person or thing; as, the Kennedy mystique
The aura of mystery surrounding the esoteric knowledge and skills required in certain occupations, or the power of those possessing those skills; as, the mystique of the astrophysicists

mytacism.definition: Too frequent use of the letter m, or of the sound represented by it

myth.definition: A story of great but unknown age which originally embodied a belief regarding some fact or phenomenon of experience, and in which often the forces of nature and of the soul are personified; an ancient legend of a god, a hero, the origin of a race, etc.; a wonder story of prehistoric origin; a popular fable which is, or has been, received as historical
A person or thing existing only in imagination, or whose actual existence is not verifiable

mythic.definition: Of or relating to myths; described in a myth; of the nature of a myth; fabulous; imaginary; fanciful; mythological

mythologic.definition: Of or pertaining to mythology or to myths; as, mythological creatures
based on or told of in traditional stories; lacking factual basis or historical validity; mythical; fabulous

mythologist.definition: One versed in, or who writes on, mythology or myths

mythologization.definition: The construction of a myth; the restatement of a message as a myth

mythologize.definition: To relate, classify, and explain, or attempt to explain, myths; to write upon myths

mythologizer.definition: One who, or that which, mythologizes

mythology.definition: The science which treats of myths; a treatise on myths
A body of myths; esp., the collective myths which describe the gods of a heathen people; as, the mythology of the Greeks

mythopoeic.definition: Making or producing myths; giving rise to mythical narratives

mythopoetic.definition: Making or producing myths or mythical tales

mytiloid.definition: Like, or pertaining to, the genus Mytilus, or family Mytilidae

mytilotoxine.definition: A poisonous base (leucomaine) found in the common mussel.  It either causes paralysis of the muscles, or gives rise to convulsions, including death by an accumulation of carbonic acid in the blood

mytilus.definition: A genus of marine bivalve shells, including the common mussel. See Illust. under Byssus

myxa.definition: The distal end of the mandibles of a bird

myxedema.definition: A pathological condition due to severe hyperthyroidism, marked by dry skin and swellings around lips and nose as well as mental and physical deterioration

myxine.definition: A genus of marsipobranchs, including the hagfish. See Hag, 4

myxinoid.definition: Like, or pertaining to, the genus Myxine

myxinoidei.definition: A suborder of hagfishes as distinguished from lampreys
synonyms: Syn. -- Myxiniformes, suborder Myxiniformes, Hyperotreta, suborder Hyperotreta, Myxinoidea, suborder Myxinoidei.

myxobacteriaceae.definition: A family of bacteria living mostly in soils and on dung; called also Polyangiaceae
synonyms: Syn. -- Polyangiaceae, family Polyangiaceae, family Myxobacteriaceae.

myxobacterium.definition: A type of bacteria that form colonies in self-produced slime; they inhabit moist soils or decaying plant matter or animal waste
synonyms: Syn. -- myxobacterium, myxobacter, gliding bacteria, slime bacteria.

myxocephalus.definition: A genus of fish including the grubb (Myxocephalus aenaeus), a type of sculpin

myxocystodea.definition: A division of Infusoria including the Noctiluca.  See Noctiluca

myxoedema.definition: A disease producing a peculiar cretinoid appearance of the face, slow speech, and dullness of intellect, and due to failure of the functions of the thyroid gland

myxoma.definition: A tumor made up of a gelatinous tissue resembling that found in the umbilical cord

myxomatosis.definition: a viral disease (usually fatal) of rabbits

myxomycete.definition: an organism of the class Myxomycetes
synonyms: Syn. -- true slime mold, acellular slime mold, plasmodial slime mold.

myxomycetes.definition: A class of peculiar organisms, the slime molds, formerly regarded as animals (Mycetozoa), but now generally thought to be plants and often separated as a distinct phylum (Myxophyta); essentially equivalent to the division Myxomycota.  They are found on damp earth and decaying vegetable matter, and consist of naked masses of protoplasm, often of considerable size, which creep very slowly  over the surface and ingest solid food
synonyms: Syn. -- true slime molds, acellular slime molds, plasmodial slime molds.

myxomycota.definition: The slime molds; organisms having a noncellular and multinucleate creeping vegetative phase and a propagative spore-producing stage: comprises Myxomycetes and Acrasiomycetes and Plasmodiophoromycetes; in some classifications placed in the kingdom Protoctista
synonyms: Syn. -- division Myxomycota, Gymnomycota, division Gymnomycota.

myxophyceae.definition: A former term for the natural family Cyanophyceae
synonyms: Syn. -- family Myxophyceae, Schizophyceae, family Schizophyceae.

myxophyta.definition: A phylum of the vegetable kingdom consisting of the class Myxomycetes.  By some botanists it is not separated from the Thallophyta

myxopod.definition: A rhizopod or moneran. Also used adjectively; as, a myxopod state

myxosporidian.definition: An organism of the order Myxosporidia, mostly parasitic in fishes and including various serious pathogens

myzostomata.definition: An order of curious parasitic worms found on crinoids. The body is short and disklike, with four pairs of suckers and five pairs of hook-bearing parapodia on the under side
